In Octo, the board is an 8x8 board. Each player divides the board into eight sections of eight contiguous squares. Play then alternates calling off rectangles for which the other player informs the number of each section within that rectangle.

name: Kellogg's World's Champions Cereal League
description: The Kellogg's World's Champions Cereal League was a game printed on the inside of a box of Kellogg's Corn Flakes. The box had to be taken apart and laid out flat in order to play. The panels on the box included the play area, a score card, and the game rules. This is considered by experts to be the first sports-related promotion in cereal-box history.
publishers: Battle Creek Toasted Corn Flake Company (Kellogg's)

name: Kölle Alaaf
description:
This is a party game full of data about Cologne and its annual Mardi Gras celebration. Based on card instructions, players must answer questions about the festival, about the local dialect, draw or pantomime something, enumerate five examples of something, etc.

The title is a traditional expression in the Cologne area, first appearing in the writings of Prince Metternich in 1635. It basically means "Cologne above all else", i.e. is the Cologners way of expressing their love of their city.

Technical details:
- Packing external dimensions: 27,5 * 20 * 5 cm,
- Weight: approx. 700 gram
- Board size: 46 * 31 cm (triple folded only 23 * 15.3 cm)
- Maps: 100 cards with 600 questions, 6 “Kölle Alaaf” cards and 4 “Klüngel” - maps
- 6 pawns (wood)
- Cubes: 1 color cube (wood)
- 1 Pappnase as minimum costume for all cases
- Age: from 11 to 111 years
- Play time: with 4 players approx. 111 min.

name: Right Off The Bat
description:
From the back of the box and the game rule book:

Right Off The Bat - a baseball game that required no skill because all plays would be determined by the roll of the dice. An accurate and exciting game that could be played anytime, anywhere, with any teams of your choice, past or present - that produced its own realistic statistics.

You begin the game with the visiting team up first. Each shake of the dice represents a pitch. Proceed around the game board until there are three outs. Leave your game piece on the 3rd out of each inning as you will begin from whatever space your third out is for the rest of the game. Keep track of each man's at bats, balls, strikes, outs, hits, etc., and enter the total hits, runs, and errors, (if any), of each inning in the designated innings on the score card. The Home Team does the exact same thing in the bottom of each inning. Be sure to remove all base runners left on base at the end of each teams ups. As in real baseball, the game is played for nine innings to determine a winner of the game. If the Home team is ahead after 8 1/2 innings of play, the Home team wins and does not bat in the bottom of the 9th.

In the game rule book, there are 3 versions of game play that can be played from this gameboard.
Basic version is approximate 30 minutes playing time.
Intermediate version is approximate 30-60 minutes of playing time.
Advanced version is approximate 60-90 minutes of playing time.
There are also optional variations of play with each version.

name: Capt. Midnight's Mexican Ringo Jumpo Game
description: Capt. Midnight's Mexican Ringo Jumpo Game comes on an 8.5X11” board for a game that utilized jumping beans. At corners are photos of Capt. Midnight, Steve & Patsy Donovan and Chuck Ramsey. Game circle is centered by logo for sponsor Skelly Oil. This game was offered in 1940 as a premium when you purchased oil.

name: Lindbergh Gravity Game
description: LINDBERGH GRAVITY GAME is a wood game made by the Hustler Toy Corporation of Sterling, Illinois. Gameboard shows New York in upper left, Paris in lower right. The object of the game is to get your glass balls from New York to Paris.

name: Snow White and the 7 Dwarfs Game
description:
Snow White and the 7 Dwarfs Game

This game was issued by Tek Toothbrush/Johnson & Johnson and produced by Einson-Freeman Co. © 1937. The cardboard sheet w/game board and playing pieces opens to 14.5x21.5". The board features choice illustrations including character portraits and inset story scenes. Has attached panel w/punch-out playing pieces and instructions. This is a simple move along the track game that has both good and bad places that one might land on.

name: Yankee Doodle Baseball
description:
Yankee Doodle Baseball from the Russell Manufacturing Co. dated 1928.

name: Willie Mays "Say Hey" Baseball Game
description:
Originally published as Say Hey! Its Willie Mays' Own Baseball Game, An Oliver Game (c) 1954 by Toy Development Co., Inc.

Later published as Willie Mays "Say Hey" Baseball Game by Centennial Game Co. in 1958.

Game comes with three spinners, one for the pitcher, one for the batter and one for the fielder. If the pitchers spinner indicates a strike or a ball then the batter can either take the pitch or swing at it. If he decides to swing he uses his spinner to determine if he in fact hits the ball and where it was hit to or if the batter misses it. Then the fielder has the opportunity to catch or field the ball. If the ball is in play a batters dial decides if the hit is a single, double, triple or home run.

There are rules for trying to bunt or steal. Things like wild pitches and passed balls are posible.
publishers: Centennial Game Co, Toy Biz, Toy Development Co.

name: Big Builder
description:
Big Builder appears to be an educational game, as it was produced in part by the Ohio State University Research Foundation and is an "Industrial Art Curriculum Project," according to the box.

In the game players move around a set of different tracks in an effort to bid on and complete major construction projects (e.g., a bridge, a dam, etc.). Each player will end up with a different set of costs and savings and can choose the profit margin that they will use to bid for each project, although they are also limited by their bonding capacity - this is $250K at the start of the game and the object is to end up with the largest.
publishers: McKnight & McKnight Publishing Company, Ohio State University Research Foundation

name: Cryptyc
description:
Cryptyc is a somewhat unusual word search game. The board is a hexagonal grid (9 cells on a side), with each cell containing a number from 1 to 20. At the start of the game, English consonants are assigned to the numbers (written in an auxiliary area, not in the grid). After that, each player looks for words that can be made from chains of adjacent cells snaking in any combination of directions, ignoring vowels and allowing a single letter to stand for a double letter.

Each player writes down their word on paper and then, on their turn, writes the appropriate consonants on the cells used and challenges their opponents to guess the word. A successful guess gives the points to the opponent, otherwise the player gets a point per cell used. In either case the used cells are out of play.

There are a few further wrinkles, including one where, if a player manages to enclose an area with his or her color and the edge of the board, he or she may claim all the enclosed spaces.

name: Forces of Valor: Battle Tactics Game
description:
Designed as a free download to promote their line of replica military figures and vehicles(mainly the 1:72 scale lines), the Forces of Valor Battle Tactics game offers surprising realism and tactical possibilities for something designed as a promotional tool.

From their website, players can download the corresponding stat cards for the figures they own; the stat cards have attributes found on most wargame stat cards- movement, weapon abilities and strength, etc.

Firing is handled with dice rolling- basically, the longer the range, the less accurate the gun. Combat has many options available giving players the option to make mobility kills and flanking shots among other things.

The game is really more or less designed for small skirmish style ground combat although air to air and air to ground rules are covered very briefly.

name: Parlor Baseball Game
description: The Parlor Baseball Game was produced by the Parlor Baseball game Company in 1903. Players roll a die with hits (HR for home run, for example) to score runs and strike outs on a square board.

name: Siebenpunkt
description:
This game which premiered at Essen 2000 is for Ages 5 and up. It is educational in nature -- children who have some ability to count are able to develop their skill. Each of the games is a bit more challenging than the last so once they master one game they "graduate" on to the next.

Initially the child simply counts. Later the child uses an included ink stamp to make a number of marks equal to a die roll. Later, players have different colored pencils and take turns coloring parts of the picture. They must figure out the number that they can color. The player coloring the most wins. So children are learning counting while they think they're only playing a game.

name: Action Ice Hockey Game
description: Action Ice Hockey by Pressman is a very simple dexterity game where each player has a stick and tries to score goals on a playing board that looks like a platter, shaped like an oval arena, with a circular wooden disk acting as a goaltender in front of a hole in the boards that is the goal.

name: Electric Baseball
description:
An application for a U.S. patent was filed in December 1927 by James M. Prentice of Holyoke, Massachusetts. Prentice was 17 years old. The patent, for "Electric Baseball," was granted less than a year later, and Jim Prentice Electric Baseball, under a variety of titles and in a variety of forms, would go on to a production run of more than thirty years.

Prentice initially sold, or at least licensed, the rights to his invention to Parker Brothers, the game-publishing giant of nearby Salem -- probably to help fund his college tuition at the University of New Hampshire, whence he graduated with a degree in mathematics. Parkers produced Electric Base Ball Game, arguably the first electrical boardgame ever, in the very early 1930s.

Despite the enduring popularity of the fondly-remembered Prentice games, their more than two dozen variations and their chronology are poorly documented, and Prentice himself (1910-2005) seems a mysterious figure to most.

Prentice regained control of his patent by the mid-1930s and set himself up in business as Electric Game Co.. One of the first products of The Electric Game Company -- perhaps the very first, and among the simplest of all Prentice baseball games -- was Electric Base Ball "version D02," featuring the "Electric Bat." Prentice evidently got rights to Parker Brothers' graphics as well. He told the Union-News that in his first year of production, he sold about a hundred games at five dollars each.

Very similar to both the D02 and the Parker Brothers game, another of the earliest varieties of Electric Base Ball was the "version DD24," also featuring the "Electric Bat." The "D" and "DD" clearly denoted editions using a single D battery and two D batteries -- perhaps the last obvious indicia in a long list of cryptic Prentice codes. The games were personally assembled by Prentice and a few assistants.

Another early-looking version of Prentice electric baseball is Wonder Baseball Game. The illustrated batter would be reused in later variations of the box lid.

Not only is Wonder again similar to the early models above, the promo literature included in the box trumpets both the Wonder game and Electric Base Ball Model D02, as well as Electric Football, and identifies all as available in 1938. Oddly, the Wonder gameboard indicates "patent pending," despite the 1928 patent used on much later models.

Wonder Baseball had an edition packaged in a slip-cover sort of box and apparently devoid of battery compartments, control buttons, and lights. It seems to be a non-electric model, perhaps a wartime revision.

Prentice saved a little money by providing box lids but no box bottoms for his games, leaving many vendors of second-hand games today to think that one part's missing. It's not. Adding to some latter-day confusion, Electric Game Co. box lids and gameboards do not always match up. Prentice was not one to waste a nickel, so it's very likely that, even while new gameboard models were being designed, produced, and sold, old box-lid inventory was being used until it was exhausted, and only at that point would new and redesigned box lids be printed.

The lid most often associated with the earliest 1930s versions of Electric Base Ball is a red box with the batter illustration above the title. Two words on the gameboard, "Baseball" is one word on the box. The source of the illustration -- the same batter seen on Wonder Baseball Game -- remains unknown.

Slightly later editions of the lid added the phrase "Big League" above "Electric Baseball" -- all in a new font -- and are in fact usually seen covering
Big League Electric Baseball Model B-4, which was produced from about 1938 through 1941. Prentice's All-American Electric Football and Collegiate Electric Basketball also debuted by 1938.

Like the earliest versions, the B-4 measures about 16x14" -- the standard dimensions of all Prentice Electric Baseball games until the Super De Luxe editions of the early 1950s.

A fourth edition of the red box replaces "Big League" with "Jim Prentice." Jim Prentice Electric Baseball, probably from about 1940, sports a version of the cover illustration on the gameboard itself.

The legend added to the fifth red box variation reads "This Game Operates Electrically Or Mechanically." Jim Prentice Electric Baseball Dual Control Model, is a little lighter on the bulbs and wiring and the need for batteries, hinting that this too is not just post-1940 but a wartime product.

A slightly simpler version of Jim Prentice Electric Baseball Dual Control Model (had two knobs, no illustration). The two Dual Control models are the only versions of Electric Baseball so far found carrying a different patent number -- confirming not only their 1942 invention, but also that they were not a Prentice design. George P Alderman and Herbert H Fredrick had been the people granted the patent on that gameboard.

The patent was later licensed to a company called Mastercraft, which produced the game as Prolectric Baseball in 1951. Mastercraft also turned out Prolectric Football and possibly other games in the '50s.

The famous "alligator-finish" white box is assumed by many to be early 1930s vintage, but this box lid is almost always seen with Models E120, 68-B, 48-B, and 63-B, all verifiably from the late 1940s. Model E120 dates to 1947. The cartoon of the swinging batter is based on an early-'30s painting by noted illustrator J. F. Kernan.

(Source)

name: Smart aS
description:
Smart aS is an educational aid with a unique equalizing system that allows a struggling student to compete competitively against a gifted student or adult.

Smart aS targets everything from colours, shapes to phonics, reading, writing, spelling and maths right up to sixth grade and beyond with additional extension curricula.

Play is as simple as: throw dice, complete maths equation and move counter that amount, draw card and answer question corresponding to square colour.

Everyone starts in the Green section the easiest game. This allows the players to understand how to play. Then each player slowly progresses as he/she masters the ability and skill to the Yellow Section, then the Blue Section and the Red Sections of the Rules & Instruction book.

Apart from the first few games where everyone is in the Green Section, additional games can have every student /player on the different Colour Coded Levels of the Rules & Instruction, playing together at the same time. This allows a child or less able student to play competitively against an able student or adult.

name: Tomb of Gold
description: 2-4 Players (archaeologists) climb 5 levels of this stunning Mayan temple to get Gold. Competitors try to steal the gold, and bring it back to their Base camp to win! Hidden dangers lie under spinning layers. For ages 10 to adult.

name: Vacation Spin
description:
This game allows the players to experience their dream vacations in exotic destinations. You can go scuba diving in Tahiti or climb the Great Wall of China for example. It involves learning interesting trivia.

Ages 12 and up There is a patented spin mechanism which shows varying prices as in real travel.

name: Cha-Cha Belgaquiz
description:
Cha-cha is the trademark of a Belgian chocolate wafer.
You could collect three different card boxes (black, yellow, red : the colours of the Belgian flag). Included were 55 cards with questions in two languages (Dutch and French, languages spoken in Belgium). All trivia questions concerning Belgium.

+ Who was the fourth king of Belgium?

+ Which chocolate based candy contains different ingredients?

+ Who was the first Belgian to walk on the moon?

+ Which famous statue has more than 600 different costumes?

If you collected the bar codes of the candy, you could get a board, dices and jettons (counters) to complete the game.

Bobby Shantz's Baseball Game by Realistic Games Mfg. Company was produced in 1954.

description: Bobby Shantz Magic Catcher Game was published by Regent Games Inc in 1953.

name: Roger Maris Baseball Game
description:
The Roger Maris Baseball Game published by Play-Rite Inc. in 1962. This Roger Maris Game has to be one of the best post-war baseball board games in the hobby. This game is different than the Maris game made by Pressman during the same year. This game was issued by Play-Rite Games of Jeffersonville IN. The box cover has two awesome pictures of Maris in his Yankees uniform. The board pictures him twice, too. the best part of the game though, are the cards. Each card has a picture of Maris & his facsimile autograph. The game includes a fabulous board, a cardboard score board, a ball & strike indicator and 88 cards to control the action. A better description will come from:

Yahoo Group ---- Baseball Games Group;antique baseball games to modern tabletop sims

at the following site

http://members.aol.com/Butch7999/BbTitles.htm

name: MicroWorld
description:
Embark on a journey as you develop new settlements and race to become the largest town. If you enjoy exploration and resource trading games, you'll love MicroWorld. As you move around the beautifully illustrated game board, you build cabins, churches, blacksmiths, trading posts, mills, fortresses, storehouses, and more. The larger your cities become, the more you are able to accomplish because each building gives your city a special benefit. Whether you enjoy building an empire passively through farming and logging, or furiously through war and pillaging others, this game lets up to six players be who they want to be and that's what makes it such a great game!

(The above description is based on text from the publisher's website: http://www.biglittlegames.com/microworld.php)

website no longer active
publishers: (Looking for a publisher), Andrew Jaster Multimedia Design

name: Dondi Prairie Race Game
description: A simple roll and move game based on a cartoon character of the times. The box claims that this is Dondi's Favorite Wild West Game.

name: Strike Out
description:
Strike Out by Moen published in 1949. Description on the box cover: The worlds champion action game for children and adults. Great fun for one and a riot for two or more. Simple enough for youngsters. Exciting skill game for adults. All the fun and thrills of America's National Pastime.

name: Yankee Doodle
description: Produced by the Crandall & Ellis Company in 1940, the object of the game is to fill in missing words from famous quotes, most of which originate in American history. It comes with 80 quote cards, 28 red, 28 white and 28 blue counters, 400 alphabet letter tiles and a Yankee Doodle Answer Book. Examples of some of the quotes used in the game include "Remember the Maine" (Richard Hovey), "Give me liberty or give me death" (Patrick Henry), "We are through with politicians. Give us Men!" (Arthur Guiterman).

name: Orbit, a Brain Game
description: A simple trivia game. Large cards with questions on one side and drawings on the other. Each drawing is different and is a clue to the theme of the questions. Answer a question on the card correctly and you can move forward and be asked the next question on the card. You keep going until all questions on the card have been asked, but if you get a wrong answer you could move backward. The first player around the board wins.

name: Bostons vs Chicagos Parlor Baseball Game
description: Bostons vs Chicagos Parlor Baseball Game features a wooden boxed game with a colored lithograph playing field and was published in 1888.

name: Babe Ruth's Baseball Game
description: Babe Ruth's Baseball Game was published in 1936. Ruth himself endorsed the game and features a color illustration of Ruth batting with a black and white inset photo of the "Babe". The game has a playing field, deck of playing cards which controls the action in the game, wooden pieces for men and score sheets.

name: The Dana Girls Game
description:
The Dana Girls were a series of mystery books similar to Nancy Drew and the Hardy Boys.

The object of this simple roll-and-move game is to be the first player to reach the finish with a set of four Clue cards. The game comes with 32 Seaman cards, 32 Ruby cards, 4 playing pieces, a die, and a game board. Clue Cards 1 and 2 are located among the Seaman cards while Clue Cards 3 and 4 are with the Ruby cards. The board's Police Station is the game's "lucky space."

name: Carl Hubbell's "Strike Three" Baseball
description:
Carl Hubbell's "Strike Three" Baseball published by Tone Products in 1946.

Game listing comes from a compilation of games created by the Yahoo Baseball Games Group. A more complete description of the game will be created from information received from members of the group.

name: Bjørnedans og apestreker
description:
Bjørnedans og apestreker (Bear dance and monkey business) is a children's dexterity game. The game includes 55 cards with different actions, and rules for four different games:


"Se hva løver kan!" (Look what lions can do!)
"Musa kan turne" (The mouse does gymnastics)
"Dyrenes sirkus" (Animal circus)
"Konkurranseturning" (Gymnastics competition)


All games are variants of players drawing a card and acting out the action described.

name: Bikuben
description: In Bikuben (The bee hive), players control a bee that starts in the center of a hexagonal hive and moves outwards by throwing two dice with six colors. The moves must correspond to the colors on the dice. When arriving the fields outside the hive, the bee collects pollen and starts over again.

name: Betty Spaghetty
description:
The game has 60 cards consisting of the head, the body and two feet of "Betty Spaghetty and her friends".

Players take turns to combine the cards in funny ways (but the feet must match!). The person to complete one figure keeps it.

The person with the most figures when the cards run out is the winner.

name: ALF'a beta
description:
ALF'a beta is a versatile card game consisting of four decks of all letters of the alphabet (including the Norwegian letters Æ, Ø, Å, and the German letters Ä, Ö and Ü), and one joker (the "ALF") in each deck.

The rules describe many variants on how to play, including learning children how to spell, enriching the vocabulary of older players, making crosswords to challenge the other players, a regular game, "The Pyramid", and two solitaire versions.

name: Gøy med klokken
description:
Gøy med klokken (Fun with the clock) is an educational children's game where the players learn to tell the time.

The game has 24 tiles with times of the day, and the players must correctly adjust the hands of the clock on the board according to these tiles.

name: Klisterhjerne
description:
A spin-off from the Norwegian TV-channel TV2's game show "Klisterhjerne".

The trivia questions are taken from the Norwegian elementary, middle and high school curriculum, and each players gets questions depending on their age. There are multiple choice and true/false questions.

name: Klokkejakten
description:
Based on the characters of the popular Norwegian song-writer and musician Alf Prøysen.

The players play the animals starting at "Dyreskolen" (Animal's school), where Miss Crow is teacher. They are looking for different items that they need at the school, but when someone finds the school bell, the school starts and they need to hurry to the school.

name: Moro å lære: Vi legger sammen
description:
The players learn how to add numbers from one to six. The players collect colored chips.

When the player believes he or she has collected the correct number of chips, the calculation is turn around and the correct answer is revealed.

The best adder wins.

name: Battle Box: WWII (Europe)
description:
A simple and fast boardgame contained within a box. One page of rules, fantastic graphics on the map, 20 plastic miniatures, dice, and hours of simple war gaming fun.

This game is not designed to simulate, it is a game. Fathers and sons, fathers and daughters, and even mothers with children will love the simplicity and speed (most games last less than 30 minutes). Old school gamers will also love it as a quick fix game.

It is 1940. Players choose the Allies or the Axis to play. The board has preset armies for both side that begin on the board. A game last 15 turns unless a clear winner before then. Some turns have preset first phase players, some the players dice for initiative. On those turns player get to go first automatically, they also receive reinforcements. Essentially, the allies must hold out until mid-game or they are going to loose. The Germans must win quick, or the allies will eventually overwhelm them. Hey! Just like the real war...

The game uses very simple mechanics for movement and combat, and it is in no way a simulation. The idea is to provide a "beer and pretzels" game for those who don't have time to play a more involved wargame.

The concept behind the Battle Box series is simple and fun: Play when you can. The game is perfect for introducing young would be generals to wargaming, as even as early as 10 years old the rules and concepts are easily grasped.

Available at www.flamingmonkeygames.com
mechanics: Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Tobac
description: Each player has four pieces (cups) with a ball (marble) in one of the pieces. Each player's pieces start in the row nearest to the player. Players maneuver their four pieces diagonally toward the other side of the board, backtracking when necessary, and passing the marble from one piece to another until one of their pieces with their marble reaches the opponent's starting row, winning the game.

name: Blåfjell
description:
Blåfjell (Blue Mountain) is a spin-off from the extremely popular children's television show "Jul i Blåfjell" (Christmas at Blue Mountain) by NRK (Norwegian Broadcasting Corporation).

Players collect red and blue hats and try to reach Blåfjell before the dusk comes.

name: Lippy the Lion Flips Game
description: Lippy the Lion Flips Game is based on the Hanna-Barbera (1962) cartoon of the same name. With Hardy Har Har the Laughless Hyena this is a simple follow the path roll and move game.

name: The Gumps at the Seashore
description:
The Gumps at the Seashore is a simple roll and move game from the 1930's.

Box has nice graphics with Andy, Chester and Min, signed by cartoonist Sidney Smith.

name: Captain Kangaroo Let's Build a House
description: Spin and move game based on the television show Captain Kangaroo. Object of game: 1) First player uses the spinner and if the hand points to blue half, he may choose any tool and place it on his tool board. He may also take a piece of his puzzle of the same color as his tool board. 2) If spinner points to the blank or the yellow half of circle, it becomes next player’s turn. 3) First player to have all six tools and all parts of his house together wins the game.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Down the Hatch
description: Down the Hatch published by Cadaco-Ellis in 1943 is a "fast action marble game". Marbles are dropped into a tower like structure and eventually come out the bottom and then land on different spots on the game board. Those spots score different amounts of points.

name: The Champion Game of Baseball
description:
The Champion Game of Baseball was published by the Proctor Amusement Company of North Cambridge, Massachusetts in 1889. It consists of a baseball field printed on the bottom of the box with a metal spinner in the middle, a rules sheet, and an envelope with nine blue and nine red cardboard disks.

There is not a lot of strategy in this early game - each team uses the spinner on its turn to bat. Most of the results are either outs or hits (spaces for single, double, triple and home run), but there also are spaces for strikes, balls and base on balls. It is therefore possible but unlikely to get three strikes or four balls. There is one space for a foul ball, and any spinner stopping on a line is considered a foul as well.

The one strategic option open to the batting team is whether to have base runners try to steal. In this event, the stealing team spins again, but uses an outer ring where the results are divided between "out", "safe" or "sacrifice" (where the runner advances but the current batter is out). An out result always picks off the lead runner.

* * see corrections in Community Wiki below

name: Dictator
description:
There were a few more real life dictators in the world when this game was published in 1939. Very little information can be found about this board game.

Update - The game comes with many lead minatures (8 Aviators representing each player, 12 submarines, 8 Battleships and 16 aeroplanes). Definitely the king of game play pieces by weight alone. The map contains a circle of spaces surrounded by 3 territories which hold the game's key resources- Manchukuo (Iron), Dutch East Indies (Oil) & Ukraine (Wheat). The game play spaces have actions (like collect $4 million or capture enemy plane) or consequences (sub sunk) and even political events (revolt, coup or treaty - which are separate cards).

The center of the board represents the armament factory and all the minatures begin there to be bought by the player as they build up their forces. The players move around the circle by the roll of the dice collecting and losing money, armaments and political cards to be used in the game. The goal of the game is to collect military forces so that you can control the 3 territories (1 at a time or if you are strong enough, all at once). The players move military units into and out of the territories on their turns, conquering weaker opponents (and taking their units). If you have the required military units in the territory and you have earned a propaganda card (by landing on the right space) you gain the resource of that territory. Having all 3 resources wins the game.

It is believed that even copies in very good to very fine condition, used copies that may even be missing a part or two, were worth between $500 and $600 as recently as the year 2000. For those looking for this game, it comes in a long red box with the word "Dictator" written across the front in red lettering on top of a curved white stripe.

name: Double or Nothin'
description: This "Follow The Leader game" includes a game board with a cartoon-like village scene, 16 Nothin cards with a boy's unhappy face, 14 Double cards with a boy's smiling face, 2 Triple cards with a boy's excited face, 4 plastic boy figures, and a white die. The cards are used to increase the die roll movement or to give the player nothin'.

name: Bokstavleken
description:
In Bokstavleken (The Letter game), a letter and a topic is revealed. The first player to name an object in this topic gets the letter.

Is quite similar to Ordjakten, but this game is restricting words to begin with a specific letter, and comes without a timer.

name: Bondegårdspillet
description: In Bondegårdsspillet (The Farm Game), the players compete to fill their board with farm animals. A spinner decides which animal the player is allowed to take from the supply. With the Farmer, the player can decide freely, but with the Tractor, no animal can be taken.

name: Bursdagsfesten
description:
Bursdagsfesten (The Birthday Party) is a children's game in the theme of Winnie the Pooh, where the players must find seven friends of Pooh and the honey he will serve in the party.

On the board, there are squares with friends of Pooh. When landing on such a square, the player must find the friend amongst the hidden markers. If the marker does not match, it is put back in the pile.

name: Den lille Havfruen
description:
Den lille Havfruen (The little Mermaid) is a Disney themed children's game where the players compete to reach the castle of Prince Eric while holding the card with the Mermaid's voice.

The players move to the shipwreck and collect cards, and then to the sea witch to get transformed. After becoming a women, the player must avoid the traps of the castle to get to the Prince.

name: Den lille røde traktoren
description:
Den lille røde traktoren (The little red tractor) is based on a BBC children's television show, where the players must direct three different tractors ("Den lille røde traktoren", "Blå Boss" and "Treske") to specific squares.

Each turn, the die is thrown and a goal square is revealed from a card. The player must choose one of the tractors depicted on the card and try to move it to the square on the card, using the exact movement of the die. If the player is successful, the player wins the card.

name: Tagalong Joe
description:
The object of this abstract game is to place five tokens of one color in a row in any direction on a special 12 by 12 game board grid or to force your opponent into three "traps" -- the twenty red squares on the game board.

The four-player version of the game involves team play while the three-player version involves one player alternatively playing against the other two.

100 points for completing a five-in-a-row formation.

Other bonus scoring include the following:
100 points for completing a five-in-a-row formation with 10 tokens or less.
50 points for completing a five-in-a-row formation within the pink square.
50 points for forcing your opponent into 3 traps.
20 points for forcing your opponent into 2 traps.
10 points for forcing your opponent into 1 trap.

This game was manufactured by Wales Games Systems, Inc., a division of Wales-Strippit Corporation in North Tonawanda, New York, USA. It was later slightly modified to fit in with the western theme of Wales Game Systems' other games, having a cowboy hat added to the drawing of Joe and becoming "Tagalong Cowboy Joe," a "64-32 Ranch Game."
publishers: The Game Crafter, LLC, Wales Game Systems

name: KUnnskap på boks
description:
(Translated from the publisher's site in Norwegian)

KUnnskap (KU=cow) på boks is a trivia and strategy game for the whole family! The game consists of general trivia questions, riddles and picture puzzles at two levels: one for mature cows (more or less adults) - and one suited for 10 year olds (playful calves) and up.

Strategy? Well, it is all about getting the largest field. The player with the largest field, wins the game! One has to use strategic cunning by colour mounds. The point is to hinder the other players in expanding their fields, while every player tries to make their own fields as large and bountiful as possible. The players amass points by solving the exercises.

På forhånd bestemmer man seg for å spille med en stor beitemark (+ 1 time) eller en mindre hvis man ønsker et raskere spill (+ 30 minutter). Spillet egner seg for 2 til 4 spillere eller lag.

Illustrasjonene er elleville og humoristiske og vil glede både store og små!

In advance the players decide either to play for a large field (60+ minutes) or a smaller one if they wish a quicker game (30+ minutes). The game is suitable for 2 to 4 players or teams.

The illustrations are hilarious and humouristic, and will please young and old!

Mooohh!

name: En for alle, alle for en
description:
En for alle, alle for en (One for all, all for one) is a cooperative childrens game where the players cooperatively move a team of mountain climbers.

The climbers are connected with a rope such that there cannot be more than two spaces between one and the next. The moves can be divided freely among all climbers.

All players win if the climbers reach the summit before the sun sets. Else they all lose.

Contents:

- Game board
- 4 mountain climbers with rope
- One sun
- 26 action cards
- One die
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Donald Ducks Bondegårdspill
description:
In Donald Ducks Bondegårdspill (Donald Duck's Farm Game), the players play Hewey, Dewey and Louis (and perhaps Phooey ?) on Grandma Duck's farm trying to collect a complete set of apples, milk, corn and egg.

Contents:

- Game board
- Wheel with needle to attach to the board
- Four playing pieces with plastic feet
- 16 pieces of apples, milk, corn and egg
- One special die
categories: Animals, Children's Game, Farming, Movies / TV / Radio theme
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Disney Bursdagsspillet
description:
In Bursdagsspillet (The Birthday Game), the players are invited to Donald Duck's birthday party and must play a round of the Hat Game before proceeding to the cake.

The players throw the dice to determine which color of the hat to move. A hat can be put on top of one single other hat, be freed on special balloon squares, or being swapped if the special die shows the party hat. When a single or double hat passes the finish line, one point goes to the player playing the color of the hat on the top.

Contents:

- Game board
- 16 hats in 4 colors
- 1 regular die
- 1 special die with colors

name: Fischer Price Bondegårdspillet
description:
In Fischer Price Bondegårdspillet (Fischer Price's The Farm Game), players compete to collect all of their food pieces. Each player controls one animal and simultaneously the farmer and his or her animal. If the farmer is adjacent to the animal (they move in separate zones of the board), the animal is fed.

The first player to get ten food pieces wins.

Contents:

Game board
Farmer figure
Four animal figures
40 food pieces
One colored die

name: Form & Gjett
description:
Form & Gjett (Mould and Guess) is a unique game where two and two players team up. Each round, one of the players of the team chooses a timed task (Foot in the air, jump like a rabbit, swing your arms etc) and tries to perform that action as long as possible, while the other player moulds whatever is depicted on the figure card. The first team to fill their sheet wins.

Contents:

Six time sheets with six tasks each
54 figure cards
Two boxes of moulding clay

name: Først og sist
description:
In Først og Sist (First and last), players try to find words starting with a given letter and ending with any letter shown on the game board. If a player successfully finds a word, he or she takes the first letter, and moves the last letter to the top of the game board, becoming the starting letter of the next word, which the next player must find.

If a player cannot find a word, the starting letter is turned around, only to become a new letter, or a joker.

Contents:

Game board
48 letters

name: Witch: Stjernespillet
description:
In Witch - Stjernespillet (Witch - The star game), players compete to reach the center of the playing field.

The sign cards tell whether the player should move forwards or backwards, and the number cards is played by the player to say how many squares she or he wants to move.

If a heart square is reached, the player must see if his or her sign of the zodiac matches one on the topmost dream boy card.

Contents:

Game board
38 sign cards
38 number cards
12 sign of the zodiac cards
12 dream boy cards
Four pawns

name: Junior Gruble
description:
Junior Gruble is a children's edition of Gruble, with easier rules and the players don't need to be able to write.

The youngest player chooses one subject on the game board and places the marker there. He or she then throws all four dice, and the first to find a word in the topic beginning with any of the four letters can put one of his chips in the same square.

The first player to place all four chips in his or her color wins.

Contents:

Game board
Four dice with letters
16 chips in four colors
One black marker

name: Spooky Spelling
description:
Three childrens games can be played with this set of letter stamps, "ghost" tins and "ghost" word cards.

In Little Ghostly Alphabet the objective is to stamp two words. The stamps are put in the tins. Then each player gets a ghost card with a word on it. The words are in multiple languages, including English. Each turn a player selects a tin, then stamps any letters which are in their word. The letters must be stamped in order.

The Word Searchers is a variation on Hangman, using the stamps.

In G as Ghost, the stamps are again put in the tins. Each player chooses a tin, then uses a stamp inside to either start a new word or extend a word that is already started. Players must announce the word they are thinking of. Other players can either stamp the letters in that word or switch to another word as long as the letters already stamped match the new word. Only three words can be started at a time. The game ends after five words are completed.

name: Geni (suppleringskort)
description:
Expansion pack to Geni, featuring 132 cards with 792 new questions, but is also playable as a stand-alone trivia game.

Is on purpose designed to have easier questions, as questions from this pack is designed for 10 years and up (originally 12).
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Trivia

name: Gambler Casino
description:
Before starting the actual game of Gambler Casino, all players must invent three prizes and write them on their note pad. (The rules suggest "Anything from a chocolate to an orange, or free baby sitting".) The players use the roulette to claim the prizes.

The prizes are won if the ball stops on a '3' or '5', and the player correctly guesses a 'higher' or 'lower' value on 3 (or 5) successive cards. The player may choose to do double or nothing with this prize. When there are only prizes of a single color left, the player with the most prizes is named "Casino Gambler of the Year" and gets the rest of the prizes.

Contents:

Game board
Playing cards
Roulette
Six note pads in different colors

name: Triolo
description:
From the front of the box:

"Triolo is a game of skill for two players. You begin with twelve counters each and take turns to place them around the network of lines on the Triolo board. Maneuver three of your counters into a straight line and you've formed a Triolo. Each time you outwit your opponent and form a Triolo you take one of his counters from the board. Form enough Triolos to remove all his counters and you win the game."

A game for all ages from 8 to 99 years.

name: Free Agency
description:
Made by LDS (Latter Day Saints) Game Factory in Placerville, CA. I don't have the instructions, but it looks as though players go around the board -- and off into little side trips like Talents, Leisure, Career, Church. Family and Education -- to gather Blessings but to avoid Trespasses. According to the score sheets, you tally each, plus add the number of side trips made to the Blessing column and it looks like the highest Blessing score wins.

Knowledge cards get you Blessings or Trespasses. Free Agency cards quote verses from LDS scripture. Corner spaces are significant: Go on a Mission or to the Tree of Life; these are the good squares. The bad ones are Temptation and Sin City. It looks like Sin City is like Monopoly's Jail square. You must roll to get out and the longer it takes, the more Trespasses you get.

name: Hjulene på bussen
description:
Hjulene på bussen (The Wheels on the Bus) is a children's game where the players try and get all their pawns on the bus that goes around the game board.

Each turn, the player first throw the die and moves the bus. If the bus gets to a bus stop with pawns on, it stops and the pawns are entering the bus (removed from the game). Then the player throws the die once more and moves one of his or her pawns.

The first player to get all pawns on the bus, wins.

Contents:

16 pawns in four colors
One bus pawn with plastic foot
One die

name: Honningspillet
description:
Honningspillet (The Honey Game) is a Winnie the Pooh-themed children's game.

All playing pieces are mixed before the game starts, and the only way to find out who controls which piece is to move to a bee square and look at the sticker at the bottom of the honey pot. The players must then remember the colors and move their own pots towards the goal.

The first player to get all his or her honey pots to the goal is the winner.

Contents:

Game board
12 honey pot pieces with plastic feet
12 stickers
1 die

name: Hopp med Pippi
description:
Hopp med Pippi (Jump along with Pippi) as a children's game in the theme of Astrid Lindgren's Pippi Longstocking.

The players play Don't touch the floor in Pippi's mansion Villa Villekulla.

Each turn, the players throw the dice with arrows (straight ahead, turn left and turn right), and try to match them with the arrows on the oncoming squares. Then the player throws the special die, and if Pippi is shown, then he or she can move a Pippi token to cover a hole in the floor. If the players fall in a hole, they miss a turn.

Contents:

Game board
One Pippi die
Four dice with arrows
Two Pippi tokens
Four pawns

name: Juliaspillet
description:
Juliaspillet is an activity game where the players get various tasks:

Dilemma: Read a dilemma aloud and guess what your friends would do.
Duel: Read a word backwards, and let the other players guess the word.
Text message: Read the message and move your pawn.

If you answer incorrectly, you are put on the merry-go-round, and cannot move until the pawn there gets to a square with a star.

Contents:

Game board
Five pawns (one to each player and one to the merry-go-round)
One die
One bell
45 dilemma cards
Two answers card
18 duel cards
15 text message cards

name: Juliaspillet: bare for jenter
description:
Juliaspillet - bare for jenter (not to be confused with Juliaspillet (2005) by the same publisher, is a game, where the players must find out who is their secret admirer.

Before starting, each player gets a boy card which they cannot look at. By completing various tasks, the player gets to see one of the other boy cards, and in the end collect enough information to correctly guess the secret admirer. If a player guesses incorrectly, she (or he) loses.

Contents:

Game board
Four pawns
One die
10 boy cards
45 task cards
One result pad

name: Herkules: Heltespillet
description:
In Herkules - Heltespillet (Hercules - The Game of Heroes), players try to collect 10 swords and return to the starting square.

Each turn, the player moves both his or her own pawn and the Hades pawn (in any direction). If landing on a hero square, the hero token there is turned over, and the player can lose or gain swords. If Hades reaches a player, they lose half their swords.

Contents:

Game board
Four Hercules pawns with plastic feet
Two dice
38 sword tokens
20 hero tokens
Four Magara pawns
One Hades pawn

name: Pot O' Gold
description:
Based on the NBC Radio game show, the main premise was giving away $1,000 per week by calling a name randomly chosen from the phone book and awarding the money to whoever answered the phone, provided s/he was already tuned in to the broadcast.

So how could this translate to a board game? Well, it attempts to recreate the excitement of waiting at home for the call, containing 12 rotary dial phone disks, a pot filled with "gold" pieces, a dice cup, paper money, and tally sheets.

name: Roodles
description:
The Game of Roodles consists of fifty-six cards composed of four series, Wishbone, Horseshoe, Shamrock and Swasticka, each series being number from 1 to 14 consecutively. The object of the game is to get rid of the cards in your hand according to the rules of the game. Roodles could be classified as belonging to the Rummy family of games.

Another information page states: The set contains 57 cards comprising 1-14 in each suit of wishbones, horseshoes, shamrocks and swastikas plus a Roodles joker card who juggles all the suit symbols.

name: Eventyrspill
description:
Eventyrspill (Fairy Tale Game) is a Disney themed Memory-like game where players must find six different Disney characters. Players move around the playing piece to turn around cards. If Cruella de Ville is turned over, the player must find one Dalmatian before he or she can win.

Contents:

- Game board
- 4 playing pieces
- 56 Disney cards
categories: Children's Game, Memory, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Running with Bulls
description:
From the instructions:

"Running with Bulls is a fun game which teaches children about, saving, investing, companies, shares, the stock market, general financial knowledge and to read the financial newspaper."

It's a roll and move trivia game with a financial theme. From South Africa.

name: Beneath the Waves
description:
Beneath the Waves (BtW) is a board-game but started as a floor-top game played entirely at shows. The game is set in a fictional world around 1870. Each player commands one or more steam punk submarines with the goal to sink the opposing side's submarines or fulfill a certain goal/mission.

In order to control a submarine usefully you have to order the crew to perform all the different tasks necessary to the running of a submarine. Then you have to decide the movement of the submarine, trying to outsmart your opponents move. While executing the movement you have to fire the weapons at the right moment to insure maximum devastation.

The game is played by two or more players. The players belong to one side or the other, Germany or the Confederate States of America (CSA). Each side has one or more submarines, three or four for a normal game.

name: Check-o
description:
From the Instruction folder:

"CHECK-O is an exciting new game, designed to entertain every member of the family. Two, three or four people can play."

"Action takes place on a board with traditional checker-squares on it, separated so that red squares touch red squares at diagonal corners and similarly, white squares touch white squares at diagonal corners. Moves by players are made diagonally."

"The object of the game is to capture opponents' men by leap-frogging over them until the checkers of only one player remain."

"It will be noted that there is a big square area in the center of the board. Wings extend in four directions giving the playing area the shape of a cross."

"CHECK-O is a direct descendant of the ancient game of Checkers, devised over 5,000 years ago by the Egyptian Pharoahs (sic), so history tells us."

"When the Roman soldiers conquered Egypt, they took home many souvenirs of their exploits in North Africa. Among these was the game of Checkers. Even in ancient times, moves were made in the same way - diagonally across the board - and each player faced his opponent with twelve men."

"CHECK-O, though similar to Checkers, is faster-moving and gives more opportunity for strategy. This is especially true in CHECK-O DOUBLES when each player must out-plan and out-think three opponents who are coming towards him from three different directions."

name: Kaptein Sabeltann og skatten i Kjuttaviga
description:
Kaptein Sabeltann og skatten i Kjuttaviga (Captain Saber-tooth and the Treasure of Kjuttaviga) is a spin-off from the Norwegian children's show character Kaptein Sabeltann by Terje Formoe.

The players compete to find the treasure of Grusomme Gabriel (Hideous Gabriel) and return it to the Pirate's Cove.

The player must first find Grusomme Gabriel's anchor, and then fight Kaptein Sabeltann with the acquired pirate cards to get to the treasure. But beware! Other players may steal the treasure and get to the Cove first!

Contents:

Game board
Four playing pieces with plastic feet
Two dice
12 Kaptein Sabeltann cards
44 pirate cards
Four red obstacles
One treasure card
Two mountains.

name: Jungeldyret
description:
In Jungeldyret (The Jungle Animal), the players play the rare jungle animal Hugo and must get to the jungle as fast as possible, avoiding the evil Izabella and her husband Konrad.

Each turn, the player first moves his or her own pawn, then Izabella's pawn. If Izabella catches the player, then the player misses a turn until they find the Rita card.

Contents:

Game board
Five pawns with plastic feet, including Izabella
Three cards (two Izabella and Konrad cards, and one Rita card)
One die

name: Jul i Skomakergata
description:
Jul i Skomakergata (Christmas at Shoemaker Street) is a spin-off from the most popular advent calendar children's show in Norway.

The players must match all shoe pairs with the correct owner, and at the same time make sure they can feed Tøfflus parsley whenever he appears.

Contents:

Game board
24 shelf cards
18 parsley cards
Four pawns with plastic feet
Four markers
One spinner

name: Das große Stromverbund-Spiel
description:
(copied from instruction sheet:)Jeder Spieler erhält 2 Figuren einer Farbe. Aufgabe ist es, als erster beide Figuren in das Ziel zu bringen. Der jüngste Spieler beginnt. Man rückt so viele Felder vor, wie man Augen gewürfelt hat. Rückwärts ziehen ist nicht erlaubt. Wer eine 6 wirft, darf nochmals würfeln.

Auf jedem Spielfeld darf nur eine Figur stehen. Rauswerfen ist erlaubt. Wer auf ein Feld mit orangefarbener Zahl kommt, hat die entsprechende Anweisung ohne Widerstand zu befolgen. Beide Spielfiguren müssen mit direktem Wurf ins Ziel gebracht werden. Wem dies gelingt ist Sieger.

(English translation from on-line translator and re-worded a bit by me:)Each player receives two pawns of the same color. The challenge is to bring both pawns to the end space. I presume this to be the giant electrical plug at the end of space 80. The youngest player begins. A player advances as many spaces as a roll of the die. No moving backwards. If you roll a six, you may roll again. Only one pawn at a time on each number. Elimination is permitted. If you land on an orange number, you must immediately follow the instructions printed on the side of the board. Whoever gets both his pawns into the end space with exact roll of the die is the winner. Only one pawn at a time on each number. Elimination is permitted.

Examples of orange space instructions:


31 says Gemeinsam duschen nach Fußallspiel spart Energie. 3 Felder vorrücken. On-line translation: Showering together after playing football saves energy. Advance three spaces.



59: Panne legt großes Kraftwerk still. 2 Runden Aussetzen. Trans: Large power station shut-down. Lose two turns.

name: Vex
description:
Equipment consists of eighty-one wooden tiles. The tiles represent three complete alphabets and three wild cards. One player draws three tiles and composes a word that uses those three letters of not more that nine letters. The other player has to guess the word. Guessing the word within six tries scores the guessing player two points. Guessing the word within eleven tries scores the guessing player one point. Stumping the guessing player scores the other player two points. The first team to twelve points wins.

When more than two play, they play as two teams.

Vex was named in the Games Magazine Games 100 of 1998.

name: Galax
description: For two or more players. Description: This is a race between the fastest ships in the galaxy. The goal is to reach the Space City in the middle of the galaxy. The player that first lands his ship there is proclaimed the winner. May the best space pilot win.

name: Raptorjakt
description: For two players. Description: Do you want to be a carnivore or a herbivore? Choose your side and head for the swamps! The players start off on opposite ends-with the task of crossing the swamp first. The herbivores need to look out so that they are not eaten by the carnivores, but the herbivores are more numerous.

name: Demonsvärdets Mästare
description: The Master of the Demonsword is a labyrinth game-here you meet dangers in the form of flying snakes, fire balls and skeletons- you will never know what turns up! DO you carry the sun mirror, the fire ointment or the thunder ball? The right object may save you! Otherwise you'll have to duel. You will need to jump on the right stones and choose the correct way in order to reach the sword first.

name: Mikke Mus-spillet
description:
Mikke Mus-spillet (The Mickey Mouse game) is a simple children's game where the goal is to be the first to skate through the park. There are various ways to the goal, and by taking shortcuts and avoiding Pluto running in the wrong directions, a player may find a shorter route through the park.

Contents:

Game board
Four pawns
Die

name: Bird-Shooting Game
description: Bird-shooting indoor target game with the subtitle "...with Harmless Gun." The contents include nicely drawn, colored and printed cardboard cut-outs of four exotic birds which, with the aid of the attached wooden supports to the rear of each, enable the bird to swivel back when struck by a cork as fired by the toy shot gun. A tabletop action dexterity game.

name: I.Q. Games: World Geography
description:
How well do you know your World Geography?

In this game, one player reads from a list of numbered clues on the back of a card while others try to guess the correct answer. You score five points for guessing after one clue and it declines to one point if all five clues are read. The last clue is a picture of the area in question and various visual clues. Players continue taking turns until all cards have been read. Score is kept on included scorekeeper. The player with the most points at the end of the game wins.

name: I.Q. Games: Famous Places
description:
How well can you identify these famous places?

In this game, one player reads from a list of numbered clues on the back of a card while others try to guess the correct answer. You score five points for guessing after one clue and it declines to one point if all five clues are read. The last clue is a picture of the place in question and various visual clues. Players continue taking turns until all cards have been read. Score is kept on included scorekeeper. The player with the most points at the end of the game wins.

name: Jim's LectraMatic Torpedo Attack
description: Maybe the first battery operated game ever produced. Torpedo attack relies upon two "D" sized batteries to power the naval warfare game board. Two opponents maneuver their battleships across the ocean while the opposing player attempts to find and torpedo them. A red light comes on when a hit is successful and a small magnet is placed upon the "damaged" ship. An interesting game that appears to have been produced in the early to mid 1960s.

name: Demon Mine
description:
Free print-and-play game where miners face off against giant beetles in a collapsed mine. Play until one side is eliminated.

The files (in html or pdf format) provide you with board and event tiles and rules. You must provide 16 pawns and 2 six-sided dice to play.
categories: Fighting, Print & Play, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Area Movement, Modular Board, Tile Placement

name: Lek og lær-spillet
description:
In Lek og lær-spillet (The game of play and learn), the players must clean up all roomes of the large house. The players move around the board, and when entering a room, the player must draw one clean up piece from the pile. If it matches the room, the troll there are removed from the room and given to the cleaning player as a trophy.

The player with the most trolls when all rooms are cleaned up is the winner.

Contents:

Game board
4 pawns
12 clean up pieces
8 troll pieces
One die

name: Lesespill
description:
In Lesespill (Reading game), the players must find the starting letters of each of the depicted objects on the game board. The players start by putting the pawns on the bottom row of the board, and proceeds by finding the correct letter of the next square. The first player to get to the top of the board wins.

Contents:

Game board
4 pawns
29 letters

name: Lurifax
description:
Lurifax is a yatzy-like game, where the players can cross out a square after a combination (like straight, house, even numbers etc) is obtained. The player has three throws to get a combination.

The first player to make to four-in-a-rows wins.
Alternative rules: The first player to make a cross or an l-shape wins.

name: Pirate Regatta
description: For two or more players. Description: Here you will need to sail fast, but also to look out for sharks and reefs. The beacon may also cause you some trouble. You have battleships and sloops at your disposal...you will need to reach the opposite shore first with one of your ships.

name: Frenzy
description:
Frenzy is an abstract game where players represent schools of fish and/or feeding sharks. Played on an 8x8 grid, the school of fish is represented by 32 stones and the sharks by 2 stones. The school fish move like pieces in Chinese checkers and the sharks move like kings in chess, capturing fish in the same fashion. The sharks win if they can eliminate the school, but a shark is also immobilized if at any time there are no adjacent fish. The school wins by immobilizing both sharks.

This can also be played with multiple boards allowing each player to play as the school on one board and the sharks on the other. By adding more boards the game can be expanded to more than two players.

name: Hexmozaix
description:
Hexmozaix is a set of 12 hexagonal tiles divided into 6 regions, 3 rhomboid regions at 3 alternating corners, and 3 chevron-shaped regions each enclosing a rhomboid. There is one tile for each possible way of coloring the regions with 3 colors such that each rhombus is a different color and each chevron is a different color (including reflections).

There are numerous puzzles provided with the set, plus two games. The tiles were created by Charles Butler, the games were presumably created or developed by Kate Jones. The games are:

Hexmozaix. Players (2, 3, or 4) take turns choosing face-up tiles until all 12 are distributed, then play one at a time to the table. Players get points for extending paths of the same color with their tile plays.

Color-Trax. Similar to Hexmozaix, except that each player chooses a color before the tiles are divided up (it is strictly a 3-player game), and scores only for that color.

There is an additional set of 18 tiles which can be added to both games, Hexmozaix II.

name: Hexmozaix II
description:
Hexmozaix II is a set of 18 tiles similar to those in Hexmozaix, but with different patterning: they have "all different arrangements of of three colors whereby two chevrons on each tile have one color, two diamonds have a second color, and the remaining two regions are the third color."

One can combine these tiles with the Hexmozaix tiles and play either of the games in that set with all 30 (allowing play of the eponymous game by 2, 3, 5, or 6 players), but the set can be used on its own as well for either game (allowing this game to be played by 2, 3, or 6 players).

Expands:

Hexmozaix
categories: Abstract Strategy, Expansion for Base-game, Puzzle

name: Quick 6
description:
In Quick 6, players participate in 6 simultaneous games of Tic-Tac-Toe, using dice to determine allowed moves.

On your turn, you roll two dice and pick one of the faces rolled for your move - there are 9 faces showing specific squares, one showing all corners, one showing all edge spaces, and one allowing a move in any square. You can move in any of the 6 grids that has the appropriate space open.

When someone achieves 3 in a row in a grid, or a grid is provably a tie, further play there is prohibited. If 3 in a row is made, the player making it scores points for the squares involved (10 for an edge, 25 for a corner, 100 for the center), and opposing players lose points for the squares they occupy.

The game seems mainly intended for 2 players (only 2 sets of dice are provided), but the rules say 3 or 4 can play using 12 grids.

name: Right Wrong: The Joys of Syntax and Lex
description:
Each player places his/her colored marker on the start circle of their game board (there are 4 individual game boards with 50 squares on each). Working in a clockwise direction each player attempts to answer 'right' or 'wrong' when read a sentence from one of 500 question cards. These sentences will have one word in them that is the questionable word and the player should determine if the word was used correctly in the sentence.

Before giving their 'right' or 'wrong' answer pertaining to the validity of the sentence the player will roll the die. If the player gets the meaning of the word correct they move forward the number shown on the die. If incorrect they move backwards the same number. The first player to reach square 50 on their board is the winner.

Ex. - She added LOVAGE to the stew on the stove.
LOVAGE = An herb of the parsley family.
So, if they answered 'right' then they move forward. If they answered 'wrong' then they move backwords. Simple!

name: Tannenberg, 17 Aug. to 14 Sep. 1914: "Railmobile"
description:
"This game simulated the campaign of the German 8th Army in East Prussia, against the invading Russian 1st and 2nd Armies, during the opening weeks of the First World War. The game is designed for 2 players, one player controlling the German forces invovled in the battle and the other player controlling the Russian forces and enables the campaign to be replayed more or less as it happened - or enabled a more skilful, or luckier, Russian commander to do better than von Rennenkamp and the unfortunate Samsonov.

The game comes with ah historical articale, a set of rules, an A4-sized map, an A4-size page of tables, 28 game counters, 28 unit strength counters and a game turn counter.

Each game turn represents 24 hours. Each hexagon represents 13x13 kilometers. Each counters represents 25-35,000 Russian infantry, 20,000 German infantry or about 10,000 cavalry.

name: BUGS! Card Game
description:
From the publisher:

Search for the scorpion. Find the fly! It's a game of fast-moving fun - all you have to do to win the game is be the quickest to find it, flip it and match it! Kids test their memories when they try to pair up matching bugs in this easy-to-learn classic memory game. Each card features beautiful hand-painted artwork by students from the San Francisco School as well as a fun fact about the featured bug, so you can learn as you play. Includes 50 Bug Cards (25 Matching Pairs) and instructions. Ages 4 and up

name: My First Brain Quest Fruit Dominoes
description:
From the publisher:

Perfect for preschool kids, Fruit Dominoes is in a child-friendly format and the original artwork is cute, cute, cute. Little ones match the fruit cards together until no more matches can be made. It's fun to play! And remember, a little bit of fruit a day keeps the doctor away! For 2 - 4 players.

name: Escape From Madagascar Stick-Ons Game
description:
From the publisher:

How can four city animals get off of an island thousands of miles from home? You can help them! Based on the DreamWorks movie Madagascar, Alex, Marty, Melman, and Gloria have been stranded on Madagascar and they need to gather Colorforms Stick-Ons pieces that spell out the world HELP. Spin the spinner and move your character around the board to collect the pieces to signal a rescue ship. The first zoo animal to collect all four pieces and get to the finish decides where the ship sails to. Beware the Foosa who lurk in the jungle! They can pop up at any time and set you back! Game comes with Game board, Character cards for Marty, Alex, Melman, and Gloria, Colorforms pieces that Stick Like Magic, Spinner, Instructions, and a special bonus Alex window stick-on! Ages 3 and Up.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Racing
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Mix N Match
description: This is an educational game intended to teach children about primary and secondary colors. This game uses clear plastic discs of various colors which, when stacked, produce other colors. Children move these colored tiles to create the most colors and collect the most points.

name: K-BAR And Bayonet
description:
From the Rulebook:

Rules for Platoon and Squad level gaming that will allow a reasonable recreation of the ferocious small unit infantry actions in the Pacific theatre of operations.
publishers: And That's The Way It Was...

name: With Ol' Gimlet Eye
description:
A skirmish level game using a variation of "The Sword and the Flame" covering the U.S. Marines in Nicaragua between 1912 and 1933

From the rulebook:

"Being a set of playable, entertaining and enjoyable skirmish-level rules that can recreate the excitement and intensity og the countless ambushes, patrols and raids in the American interventions in Central America"
publishers: And That's The Way It Was...

name: Sen-Tens cards
description:
Sen-Tens cards is a card game where each player makes "headline-style" sentences using the cards in their hand as well as the cards available in the community pile.

Each player gets four cards, and four cards are set in the middle. On each turn a player makes a sentence, which is scored by adding the numbers on each card in the sentence. When complete, the cards are set aside, and the community cards are replaced from the deck for the next player in turn. Play continues until someone cannot make a sentence.

name: Space Voyage
description:
Acting as a Commander in the Space Voyage fleet, players construct, crew and kit out a ship to voyage amongst the stars, seeking out rare minerals, avoiding alien races and trying to return to Earth as the richest Commander of the Fleet.

You start by trying to complete your ship, which is mostly a luck-driven process, before launching the ship into the void. Once launched, players try to land on mineral rich planets, but there are many hazards to avoid.

The game ends when at least two ships have returned to Earth. At this point there is a final semi-random determination of each player's holdings. All loans are settled and the winner of the game is the player with the most money.
mechanics: Commodity Speculation, Roll / Spin and Move

name: The Easter Game
description: The goal of the game is to collect 2 jelly beans, 2 eggs, and 2 chicks. Each player has a spinner with these objects depicted on them and the first to claim all of them wins.

name: Trouble Catch
description:
A boardgame based on the Japanese comic strip Urusei Yatsura. Each player plays one of four characters from the comic: Lum, Ataru, Mendo or Shinobu. The players compete to obtain presents.

Components include mapsheet, stand up figures, and 3-d presents.

name: Sheriff of Dodge City
description: A simple game in which players must spin a spinner to determine movement. If a player reaches a space with an outlaw token they spin the spinner again to see whether they "hit" and capture the outlaw (picking up the token) or miss and have to move again. The first player to capture at least three outlaws and get back to Dodge City wins.

name: That's Disgusting
description:
From the publisher:

"The hilarious drinking game where you and your friends attempt to OUT GROSS each other. Four gruesome categories and over 400 disgusting actions! Ham it up by doing overacted impersonations, name items that fit into vulgar categories, judge your friends in their efforts to gross each other out, and much, much more!!! Packaged in a dog poop shaped tin."

Components: Deck of cards, pad, pencil, custom six-sided die.

name: Hump!
description:
"The game of erotic education and sexual satisfaction!"

"You and your lover learn about each other's libidos while traveling around the game board. The woman asks the man erotic questions about how to please her, and the man asks the woman erotic questions about how to please him. Some cards offer general love-making tips and others are more personal to the likes and dislikes of the lover asking the question. The winner enjoys the reward of selecting three cards to interpret and act out during lovemaking."

"Includes: a durable gameboard, 52 Ask Him cards, 52 Ask Her cards, two game markers, a die, and easy-to-follow instructions. Packaged in an attractive game tin!"

name: Mitt aller første kryssordspill
description:
Mitt aller første kryssordspill (My very first crosswords game) is a game that introduces children to the concept of crosswords. During a turn, the player must try to find as many letters as possible to a given word amongst the hidden letters.

There are two game boards, one for the smallest children with with all letters written down, and one for older children that can spell, with some blank squares.

Contents:

2 game boards
84 letter tiles

name: Månetoppen
description:
Månetoppen (Moon Top) is a spin-off from the children's television show "Jul på Månetoppen" (Christmas at Moon Top) by NRK (Norwegian Broadcasting Corporation).

The players must collect as many blueberries as possible before the winter comes.

After finding a blueberry, they can immediately to the start square, or continue searching for blueberry, risking to lose the bucket and all collected berries.

Players
Contents:

Game board
4 pawns
36 månetoppen cards
45 blueberry cards
4 blueberry buckets
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Kahovka: Wrangel's Kursk, Oct. 14, 1920
description:
On October 14, 1920, the last major White offensive took place. It would become Wrangel's Kursk, a precursor to that more famous WW2 battle at Kursk but this happened at Kakhovka, a small town astride the Dnepr River.

Unique for it was only the second time in the RCW that a mass tank attack would occur (the first was in the Summer of 1919), fully supported by DH9A bombers and infantry against a very well prepared Red defense consisting of three consecutive trench lines, mines and barb wire. WW1 was in effect "revisited". General Wrangel placed his blind faith in the tanks he had procured from the British, His tankers were well trained. He had even developed a combined arms approach. His forces, though outnumbered by 2 to 1 or more, continued to fight the "good fight" and had busted out of the Crimea in June, sent the Reds fleeing backwards for hundreds of miles with mass tank attacks and the ideal flat land. However, Wrangel was unable to secure the town of Kakhovka. The town had little real tactical value except for the fact the Reds held it. In September, several battles had been fought for it, each time the Whites were repulsed. Oct. 14th would be the last one.

The Reds had created antitank formation consisting of MkV and FT-17 tanks and a unique American weapon, the Maklen 37mm AA gun. True, they only had a few of them , but the weapons ability to penetrate armor at very long distances was a stopper. Artillery units in AT mode also had been created. In manpower, the Reds had overwhelming strength if they did not flee from the tanks as they approached.

The stage was set for the massive tank assault (in RCW terms) and for the final show-down between White and Red.

Game scale is 1 hr turns, 800 yd a hex, company level, individual MkV, Whippet, Ft-17 tanks, Austin Armor Cars, DH9A Aircraft. The system never plays the same as once never knows how many units they can activate.
categories: Civil War, Print & Play, Wargame, World War I

name: Animal Fair
description:
Card game with a deck of 40 animal cards. As each card is turned over players collect cards by being the first player to correctly make the sound of the animal pictured on the card.

Link to rules now posted below.

name: Allie Patriot Game
description:
World War One era Patriotic card game features a deck of 48 cards for US, Britain, France and Italy. Actually this card deck features 8 different games.
1. Liberty Bond Game 2-4 Players try to collect the most Liberty bond cards while getting rid of all their other cards.
2. Organization3 - 5 Players A bidding and trick taking game where the country listed on the first card turned over acts as trumps. You must follow suit, play off suit of use a trump card to win the trick.
3. Mobilization A memory testing game for from 3 to 8 players.Somewht like Go Fish.

4. Mobilization 2 Sort of a solatiare game with the object being to build up 8 piles with all of the cards from a particular conutry.

5. Mobilization 3 A two person game where you try to mobilize all of the cards that you hold.

6 Sham Battle a bidding game where layers bid to determine county in power somewhat similar to game of canasta with different combinations being worth different values.Flag and Army of any nation worth 10 points, flag and aramy of Country in powere worth 40 points etc.

7. Sham Battle 2 try to accumulated different combinations of different cards.

8. Flag Game

name: All Star Comics Card Game
description: A trick taking card game featuring famous cartoon characters from the 1920's and 1930's. The dealer turns a card to determine a penalty suit. If Krazy Kat, Ignatz Mouse or Offissa Pup are turned up, the dealer may choose the suit before he looks at his cards or he just turns the next card to determine the suit. After all the tricks are taken, each player puts one coin in the pot for each penalty suit card taken. If any players take no penalty suit cards then they win the pot.
categories: Card Game, Comic Book / Strip, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Pinky Lee and the Runaway Frankfurters
description:
A frankfurter is placed on each one of the designated spaces along the track on the gameboard. In turn, each player rolls the die and advances one's own wagon along the track. The first to land on each frankfurter captures it and loads it on one's own wagon. Landing on an opponent forces the opponent to surrender all the owned frankfurters to the frankfurter hiding place at the finish line. The first to arrive at the finish line captures all the frankfurters that are there. The player with the most frankfurters after all have finished is the weiner (pun intended).

Pinky Lee was a Vaudeville comedian who achieved fame as the host of nationally televised children's show.

name: Would You Believe?
description: Spin and move game based on the TV show "Get Smart" . Players try to help max recover the payroll that was stolen by agents from KAOS.

name: Sorry About That!
description: Spin and move game that came on a single sheet of cardstock, from which the player punched out the playing pieces. Originally sold for 29 cents in discount stores.

name: "Get Smart" Electronic Question and Answer Quiz Machine
description: Trivia Quiz game baed on the the TV show "Get Smart".
categories: Children's Game, Electronic, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Spies/Secret Agents, Trivia

name: I'm George Gobel
description:
Roll and Move game based on the NBC TV show "The George Gobel Show" which ran from 1954 thru 1960.

The game board features many of the famous "Gobelisms" that George would often say on the TV Show.

name: My Fair Lady
description: Children's game based on the Broadway Musical "My Fair Lady".

name: Bridge Dice
