Spark is an Icelandic (language dependent) trivia game focused on football (soccer). The six categories of questions are about (1) modern Icelandic football, (2) history of Icelandic football, (3) national competition, (4) English football, (5) world clubs and (6) football players.

This game is (by the publisher) intended to be for players 8 to 108 years old. 4150 questions in all, on 1000 cards.

name: Witches and Liches
description:
From the publisher's description:

In the heart of a dark dungeon the Lich waits, pacing the floor around its treasure. Just outside the chamber door the Witch takes a deep breath of the stale air. This is the climax of the story, the last battle.

The Wicked might triumph, retrieving the Elixir needed to control the moon. The Dead might triumph, collecting the final soul needed to break his chains.

An 8-page 5.5" x 8.5" booklet. You need dice and coins, as well as the map on the back of the booklet, to play.
publishers: Itesser Ink, Wicked Dead Brewing Company

name: What's What?
description: According to the rules, the object of the game is to score the highest total of correct answers t oquestions on historical events, famous landmarks, capitals, principal cities, world currencies, and national heroes. Questions are in a booklet with answers referenced to a number on the "dial-a-matic" answer panel. Answers are limited to the US States (for the US series questions) or a limited list of countries and regions as well as yes/no (for the worldwide series questions). The game includes thirty series of 24 questions (12 US / 18 Worldwide), each of which makes up a round in the game. The winner is the first person to win three rounds.

name: Vega
description:
The players try to found colonies on planets. They need suitable space vessels to do so. Those space ships will be built from different modules (up to six per ship). It is crucial to get the modules you need to build space crafts as efficient as possible.
You exploit resources and as your empires grows there will be conflict and maybe you extinct all other lifeforms in the universe.

You can add a second game of Vega to have a bigger (modular) map. Instead of playing the standard game you also can play some specific scenarios.

The game consists of
1 Map (9 modular pieces)
12 Objects (planets and asteroids)
4 Sets of colored space ships and 4 Colonies
36 Resources of value 1 to 6
4 Sets of standard moduls (each 9 distinctive ones)
3 Sets of expansion module (18 different ones)
1 die and rules booklet

Home Page: http://www.bruex.net/vega_01.html
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Open Drafting

name: Hop Off: USA Edition
description:
Description from the Publisher's website @

http://www.borderlinegames.com/hopoff.html

It's geography hopscotch - hop on and you're off and learning about the geography of the United States!

Play with one or more teams!

For each player's turn, a team leader draws one state card from the deck. Standing on either the Pacific or the Atlantic Ocean side, the player has three chances to toss the bean bag onto that state.

When the player has succeeded in tossing the beanbag onto his target state, he hops from one ocean, across the map, naming aloud each state he hops on as he "travels" - that way everyone is learning their United States geography! When he reaches a state that borders his target state, he retrieves the beanbag and continues hopping off to the ocean on the other side.

The team wins when it has "traveled" to all 48 contiguous states!

Time your team for even more fun!

Play with the capitals only, or with both the states and the capitals for a real challenge!

name: Eine Reise mit der Eisenbahn
description:
A really old train travel game with the usual point-to-point movement mechanism.

What makes it something special is the possibility to use a second train in certain variants and the nice train-theme artwork.

Unfortunately no little loco pawns involved, only wooden cylinder pieces.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: The Game of Picture Postcards
description: Kids game in which players compete to collect sets of postcards featuring famous locations of the day.

name: The Great Obstacle Race Game
description: Rather than roll-and-move, players pull cards for their movement. The goal is to get around the board which shows something like a county fair with the sack race and three-legged race.

name: Aerial Contest
description: The pawns in this roll-and-move game look like the Wright Brothers' flyer. It's amazing that although published in 1910, this game involves flying all over the world.

name: Stop Thief
description:
Two players compete in trying to collect all the cards in the deck. To play, all cards are dealt one by one to each player face down in a pile. The dealer goes first and flips over his top card from his pile onto the center of the table. The other player flips over his top card onto the played card. If the player places on top of the pile a card with a number (Officers), he captures the pile unless his opponent can recapture them. Recapture is achieved by the player flipping over an Officer card in the amount of turns of the previous displayed numbered card. For example, if the player placed a ‘Cop’ card which is numbered 3, then the opponent would have 3 turns to try and place on top of that card another numbered Officer card. If he cannot recapture, his opponent gets to take all the cards in the pile.

Stop Thief consists of 32 cards. There are 20 thief cards and 12 officer cards. The officer cards include 4 cards depicting each a detective, cop, and police chief.

name: Armed Warfare
description:
ARMED WARFARE covers all aspect of surface warfare during the WWII era.

Armor, infantry, mines, artillery - on and off board - aerial interdiction, amphibious landings, open and urban terrain. The size of the arena can be any size players desire, 2'x2' with a few men to 4'x8' with lots of men and/or tanks. Shooting ranges extend out to eight feet. The rules are based on - What you see is what you get. One on one. Info is provided for almost every vehicle and general type of small arms from 1936 to 1954. All scales can use the rules: micro to 1/35th. Large number of vehicles will use the main rules and the few specially for that scale. 15mm to 1/35 will probably be infantry combat with a few supporting vehicles. These will use the main rules, the few rules for the large figures and the matrix for receiving wounds. The matrix is designed so a man might be hit, wound and live to fight some more. The last part would be at a reduced ability. A man hit in the left arm can still shot a pistol with his right hand.
categories: Fighting, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: The Black Experience
description:
A role and move game designed as an educational tool to 'foster pride, dignity and self awareness'.

A large colorful gameboard is included with 4 cube playing pieces, 11 Red cards and 17 Blue cards. Instructions are printed on inside of box cover.

"The Black Experience" is designed to emphasize some of the many contributions that Black people have made in Medicine, Technology, Literature, Government, Sports, Entertainment and other fields.

name: Danger Pass
description: The players must get at least one wagon from an Eastern Town to West City safely, avoiding Indians and other dangers on the trail.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Club 3
description:
Club 3 was first published as game in the magazine in "WIN" #45, the zine of the "Spielekreis Wien" in Austria. It was published in the Swiss gaming zine "AHA" two months later.

The game is somehow a derivate of Poker - with less cards, less combinations, but more interactions between the players.

The card deck consists of only 24 cards; 4 suits of 6 cards, numbered from 1 to 6.

There are only 3 combinations with a little strange names:
- Wortklauberei (logomachy): 2 cards with numbers directly adjacent each other
- Redeschwall (flood of words): 2 cards with the same numbers
- Phasendreschen (to rant): 2 cards, 1 showing an "1", the other a "6"

Each round is played with 4 cards per player; there is no possibility to exchange any of them. The first player, who thinks he has a good hand, starts the game by playing 1 card and any number of chips on it. This bet can be attacked by any player. The attacker can choose, if he wants to attack alone or with the help of another player. That means, that the original better can be forced to play against 2 players! An important restriction is, that a maximum of 3 cards can be used on each side, which would form 1 or 2 combinations.

The game ends after a preassigned time and the player with the most chips is the winner.

name: High Noon
description:
High Noon was published in the Swiss gaming zine "AHA" #87/4.

The board consists of 12 spaces, where 12 subsequent races are carried out.

Each of the 4 players has 1 token and a set of 6 cards, numbered from 1 to 6. These cards are used to move the tokens. Every turn, all players play one of their cards simultaneously. Passing other tokens is possible at the cost of 2 movement points, but landing on occupied fields is forbidden; such a move would forfeit.

While the first race starts with all tokens off the board, the following 11 races leave all tokens where they have been at the end of the previous race. But the finishing line will be shifted by 7 fields.

Up to 12 points can be won per race and the winner is the player with the most points after all 12 races.

name: Godzilla
description:
Godzilla was published in the Swiss gaming zine "AHA" #88/1.

The game is played on a 10x10 board. One player plays with Godzilla, the other one plays with 6 people/tokens from Tokyo. Each of the 6 Tokyo tokens has a different colour and wears an imaginary weapon of the same colour.

Before the game begins, the Tokyo player places 40 houses, 10 monster-immune houses and his 6 tokens on the board. Godzilla waits outside the board.

The Godzilla player is dealt 6 cards showing the 6 colours of the weapons. He is immune against 4 of the 6 weapons and to document which ones, he secretly keeps 4 of the 6 cards.

During a turn, the Tokyo player must move 3 of his tokens by 1 space, the Godzilla player moves Godzilla by 2 spaces. Godzilla can destroy houses, but not Tokyo tokens or monster-immune houses.

The Tokyo player wins, if he can move one of his 2 tokens with a "sharp" weapon on the space where Godzilla is. Godzilla wins, if he can destroy 15 houses before he is killed.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction
mechanics: Area Movement, Enclosure, Point to Point Movement

name: Proceso
description:
From the back of the box:

"Since September 27th, 2004, the Dominican Republic has a new criminal procedural law, based in an accusatory system, which replaces the one from 1844 that was inspired in the old French code based in an inquisitive model.

In order to announce the new legal frame, the Escuela Nacional de la Judicatura presents this process in a ludic educational form to the justice servers, the Policía Nacional and to the citizens in general."
publishers: Escuela Nacional de la Judicatura de la República Dominicana

name: Auction Letters
description: The game consists of 56 letter cards and play money. Cards are drawn one at a time, and placed for auction. The first player to successfully spell a word of four or more letters with his or her cards wins.

name: The Overland Limited
description:
The game box features a train going by a cowboy and horse as the cowboy waves.

The game has a spinner and the board features a green background with pink, dark green, yellow, and orange paths. The object of the game is to make money transporting passengers over a train route.

name: Tom, Tom, the Piper's Son
description: This is an old children's spin-and-move game. The cover features Tom carrying a pig running away from the butcher. There is a spinner and the board features red and blue line paths with small circles representing the places for the tokens to stop.

name: Hostesse De L'Air
description: This game comes with 6 colored airplanes, dice, and various cards. The board has square spaces and several different colored tracks to advance on.

name: Care Bears Quest for Care-a-lot Card Game
description: The goal of the game is to lay down matching sets of Care Bear cards and be the player with the Care-a-Lot card at the end of the game.

name: Ensimmäiset värini
description: A game for small children in which players learn to know colors and make combinations of colors together with Winnie the Pooh and his friends. The first player to gather six colors wins the game.

name: Solar Bases
description:
This game uses a space exploration theme to teach players about number bases (binary, octal, decimal, etc.). Each player starts play with a "matrix card," a supply of plastic chips and a "flight sheet" for scoring. Gameplay consists of five flights, each containing two phases: "Blast Off" and "Establishing a Flight Path." After five flights have been completed, the player with the highest total score is declared the winner.

During the "Blast Off" phase, the player voted mission commander draws and announces cards from a special deck of playing cards containing the standard four suits but only the numbers 1 through 9 (Ace is replaced by 1, and no face cards are included). Players place chips on their matrix cards, Bingo-style, until every player has at least one complete row or column of chips. At this point, players choose from among the 3- and 4-digit numbers filled in on their cards to establish "flight numbers," which are written on their sheets.

In the "Establishing a Flight Path" phase, players are dealt cards from a second deck of "base cards." Some of these cards contain game-balancing bonuses and penalties which apply only when drawn by players holding specially-marked matrix cards. The remaining base cards list a planet of the solar system, the number base that the planet represents in the game, and a list of digits which are valid in the planet's base. For example, Mercury represents binary (base 2), so only digits 0 and 1 are allowed. The player replaces all illegal digits in his or her flight number with zeroes, then converts the resulting number to decimal using a special base conversion wheel included with the game (except for landings on Pluto, which already represents base 10 and requires no conversion). The final result is added to his or her score.

The game includes two sets of rules -- "Brief Instructions" which get players started in just two pages, and a 10-page "Guide Book" which includes more detailed instructions, game variations and mathematical background information. The game was filed as U.S. Patent 3,618,952.

name: Starpower
description: Players have a chance to progress from one level of society to another by acquiring wealth through trading with other participants. Once the society is established, the group with the most wealth is given the right to make the rules for the game. The power group generally makes rules which maintain or increase its power and which those being governed consider to be unfair. This generally results in some sort of rebellion by the other members of the society.

name: Combat Engineer Game
description:
Relive those exciting Cold War Conflicts!

A unique game developed to impart knowledge of Combat Engineer practices and procedures to US soldiers.

* Test your general and specific military knowledge against that of other combat engineers, for two to six MOS 12B or 12C at squad, platoon or company level.
* Three folded sections of Game Board, with hex battlefield
* Organization cards, 1 for Soviet, 1 for Engineer Company (2 sides)
* 450 counters
* 1 dice
* 6 plastic card holders
* set of small cardboard boxes to hold parts until you need them
* 20 mission setup packets
* 3.5" deck of cards
o Mission Cards
o Question/Answer Cards
o Fortune of War cards

name: L'Imagination au Pouvoir
description:
L'Imagination au Pouvoir ("Imagination in Power") was published in the Swiss gaming zine "AHA" #88/2. It is a challenging game about the confrontation between the police and the protesters during a fictive demonstration.

The game includes 15 demonstrator tokens and 4 leaders of protest marches on one side; 10 policemen, 10 anti-demo troups, 3 police cars, 3 anti-demo cars and 1 water gun on the police side, but only some of those tokens are placed on the board, when the game begins:

- the 4 protest march leaders start from all 4 corners of the board, 8 demonstrators are place anywhere on the board.
- the 10 policemen and the 3 police cars are placed on the 3 police headquarters.

Each turn, 1-4 demonstrators enter play - if there are tokens left outside the board (demonstrators can be arrested in prison for 2 turns). The anti-demo tokens enter play, when the demonstrators have succeeded to win some morale points and the Morale Index has reached a value of 9.

The so called "Morale index" is a scale from 1-15 points. The game starts with a Morale index of 6. Successful actions (winning fights, repulsements of opponents, finished protest marches, imprisonments and others) change the index by 1 or 2 points.

The game can be won either by eliminating all opponents or when the Morale index reaches 15 (demonstrators victory) or 0 (police victory).
mechanics: Area Movement, Secret Unit Deployment, Variable Player Powers

name: plus and minus game
description: You spin a spinner which as numbers to add and subtract and you move buses around to different buildings collecting apple tokens when you finish at the schoolhouse. When there are no more apple tokens, the game is over. The buildings and buses themselves are tiles themselves. This is a part of the Schoolhouse in a Fun Box series be Ed-U-Cards. Quite clever use of a roll & move mechanic to teach simple addsition and subtraction.

name: What's the diff?
description:
Players detect the subtle differences between different pictures within each set. They they match the card with disconnected parts to the corresponding complete picture.

Game Contains:

8 sets of cards,
4 Level 1 set (magician, cat, baby buggy, clown)
4 Level 2 sets (cake, rooster, house, boat)

Total 48 playing cards

name: Diceoku
description: Diceoku is a sudoku based dice game for the whole family. Expert players can take on novices in a fast paced game where the highest scoring player wins. With several different strategies available, you can race to the end and stop the game or take your time for the perfect sudoku score. Barter for opponents numbers and upset them by stealing the points. All components are made from recycled, recyclable or biodegradable parts. Suitable for ages 8+

name: Desperately Seeking
description:
Let the good times roll. Toss the cubes of fate and create millions of outrageous and hilarious combinations of personal ads. Never the same ad twice. In this fast-paced game of self-celebration, you race against the clock, using as many cubs as possible, to set up the last word in relationships between imaginary (and not so imaginary) characters.

The game abounds in elements of romantic mystery, hyperbole, white (and not so white) lies, crazy juxtapositions, wild adjectives, clichés and codes, all blending to create some of the most humorous reading and exciting game play ever. Its entertainment values cannot be matched.

name: United States Trading Game
description: Each player starts with $10,000 and a pawn at Bangor, Maine. There are three cards for each of eight commodities. Each commodity may be bought, one at a time, in any one of three different cities. Each commodity may be sold when a player holds all three cards of that commodity at a profit in San Francisco, St. Louis and New York. Players are free to barter with each other. In turn, a player rolls the dice and advances one’s pawn along the path the total value of the dice. A player may stop short to conduct business in a city. Some spaces between cities force a player to draw a chance card. Some routes between cities only allow one-way traffic. The game ends when a player reaches New York with all three cards of one commodity. That player receives a $1000 bonus and all players must cash in their commodities at face value immediately. The player with the most cash is the winner.
mechanics: Pick-up and Deliver, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Corky Clown Big Top Circus Game
description: A very simple roll and move game from the late 1950's where you attempt to place your Big Top Animals on the clowns' face (Board) depending on what number you've spun with the spinner.

name: Shariland
description: This game features Shari Lewis with Lamb Chop and Charlie Horse + Friends. Game features puppets of Lamb Chop and Charlie. There are also cards, a spinner and an instruction booklet. Game is for youngsters. The box advertizes that there is "Nothing to Read or Count" and that the "Play is by Color"
categories: Action / Dexterity, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Sufficient
description: The game of Sufficient is played using a deck of 99 cards (11 cards of each of the letters of the word SUFFICIENT. The game is a rummy type game where the object is to rid yourself of your hand. Since there are two I's and two F's in the word SUFFICIENT the I's and F's have either line under them or not. On the deal, players are dealt 8 cards face up in front of them. This is called the SUFFICIENT PILES and they are also dealt 8 cards into their hands. The effort is to spell the word Sufficient using both the cards in your hand and in the SUFFICIENT PILE.

name: Jogo do Sushi
description:
From the publisher:

"Using the chopsticks, you and your friends will have fun picking the sushi fo the ray and placing it onto your plate. Sushi or sushiman, what will show up on the next tile? Be quick and grab as many sushi as you can, just don't drop them! Jogo do Sushi. Taste this delicious game!"

name: Snooker-U!
description:
Tagline: Enjoy the fun and strategy of "snookering" your oppenent! For 2-4 players of 8 years and above.

Snooker-U! is a board game for 2 players, or 4 players as two teams. The board, resembles a snooker table but is marked out with red and other coloured squares, 2 "S" squares and 2 "Foul Shot" squares.
15 red markers are placed in a triangle and 6 other coloured markers in occordingly.
A white cube, representing the white ball is placed in the break position.

The player throw the dice and moves the white ball the correct number of spaces in any direction to land on a red square. He removes a red counter from the board and scores 1 point. He throws again and tries now to land on a coloured square. If he fails, the other player takes the turn.

The game end when all counters are removed.(Black as last.)
The team with the highest number of point scores.

name: Rummy 400
description:
Rummy 400
"This great new board game makes for more runny excitement. Perfect for family and friends. Ages 9 to 90. Rummy on the fast track with shortcuts, come from behind surprises."

Players build a sequence rummy hands refilling and playing again until no more runs or sets can be exposed. Then the next player takes a turn. Players try to gain particular point values to let their marker land on the shortcut squares.

Contents: Game board, 8 player markers, instructions with a VHS video, 2 decks of playing cards

name: Opening Day: A Deer Hunters Game
description:
Trivia type game with over 400 Question Cards that address topics including:

Hunting:

Ethics
Saftey
Tracking
Trailing
Stands and Stand Hunting Techniques
Drives and Driving Techniques
Clothing
Scouting
Field Dressing
Venison Care
Bow and Gun Equipment and Shooting


Deer:

Hearing and Reaction
Deer Odors and Foreign Odors
Vision and Camouflage
Bedding
Feeding
Tracks and Prints
Trails and Movement
Body Language and Communication
Scrapes and Rubs
Reaction to Hunting Pressures
Age and Size
Antlers
Anatomy
Range and Subspecies
Weather and Deer Movement
Foods
Cover Requirements

name: Hooked on Phonics: Pop Fox's Roll and Read
description:
Roll the dice and complete as many words as you can. Collect word cards as you fill in the blanks. When all the cards are collected, the player with the most cards is the winner.

This fun and fast-paced dice game reinforces: first letter sounds and simple spelling.

From the publisher:

Roll out the letters! Then use the dice to fill in the spaces to complete as many word cards as you can. Roll and Read is an exciting skill-building game for beginning readers. Roll and Read give kids several levels of difficulty, so kids can learn and play at a skill level that is just right for them.
categories: Children's Game, Educational, Memory, Word Game

name: 1916: Land War in the Age of Machines
description:
Free set of World War One miniature wargame rules provided by War Times Journal, covering all fronts and nations. This rules are based on the 1943 game system, the War Times Journal game system that covers the World War II.

Rules can be found in the War times Journal Web site: www.wtj.com

name: Battlefleet 1915
description:
Free set of naval miniature wargame rules for World War I period from War Times Journal. This set is based on the pre-dreadnought rules from the same publisher.

The rules can be obtained from: www.wtj.com

name: De Gele Trui
description: This game was published by Belgian newspaper Gazet van Antwerpen in the 1970's. It contains a large board that measures 73x59cm. and is played with two decks of regular cards. On the board is a map of France since the goal is to win the Tour of France. There are 10 stages, the players who scores best overall wins the Tour de France.

name: The Self Defense Game
description:
From the publisher's website:

Finally an easy way to learn self defense techniques!

Defense techniques to 16 of the most common attacks are presented. Learn self defense while you play. Comes complete with a set of rules for a very enjoyable game. Create sequences of cards to repel the attacks.

Each card has:

A technique beautifully illustrated
Preceding sequence card indicator
Following sequence card indicator
Technique's name in English, French, and Japanese

The goal of this game is to repel your opponents' attacks while successfully landing your own. Players can learn self defense techniques from the cards while they play the game.

name: Cyclo Prestige
description: Cyclo Cross game made by Jan Moerman from Gent. It uses tiles that form the board, cardboard riders and tactical cards for movement.

name: Il Giro di Francia
description: Italian cycling game published in July 1969. Goal is to win the Tour de France. The game contains 6 cupboard cyclists (1 for each player) and a board that measures 23x26cm, it depicts 9 stages (including 2 time trials) on the map of France.

name: Campioni e Gregari
description:
Campioni e Gregari is an Italian cycling game released in May 1962.

What makes it interesting is that each player gets 2 cupboard figures, a leader (campioni) and a helper (gregari) and these cupboard figures happen to have drawings of real cyclists with their names mentioned on it, this makes it a collectors item for cycling fans.

The 12 riders included are Rik Van Looy, Plankaert, Carlesi, Pambianco, Battistini, Baldini, De Filippis, Nencini, Massignan, Ronchini, Daems and Suarez.

The board contains 90 squares with different actions depending on which squar a cyclist arrives. He who reaches square 90 before he other wins the game.

name: Carreras Misteriosas
description: Spanish game from the '60s, the title means "Mysterious Races", it combines a car, horse and cylcing racing game but the rules are better suited to a horse race. Thus the game includes horses, cars & cyclists. This game can be played solo, or else you can bet on the outcome.
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Bajando el Puerto
description:
Spanish cycling game from the '60s. What makes it remarkable is that the board has a downhill racing track on it, which makes it quite unique.

This game was included the game compilation "Juegos Reunidos" (usual Spanish denomination for games' combination boxes). Corominas released a series of boxes in 1962. The smaller one was of just 5 games, the bigger one of as many as 40 games. In some of the boxes was included this simple cycling game called "Bajando el Puerto", "En descendant le port", "Walking Down The Port". The rules were trilingual, really strange in Spain at the time. The game is remarkable for its graphics, and also because it is the only game I know that represents a downhill race.

name: Sammlung Schöner Spiele
description: This austrian game compilation includes the following games: Schach, Der Schatz von Omschag (a treasure- and big game hunt in africa), Glockner-Fahrt (a car rallye), Vier-Länder-Tour (a bicycle race), Halma, Mühle, Dame, Karten Galopp (a horse race card game), Truwi (Mikado).

name: Slow Bicycle Race
description: English cycling game where strangely enough the last rider to arrive wins! The board has 4 tracks for each participant.

name: Ambientolito
description: Ambientalito is an educational game that takes care about the environment and sustentable development.

name: South Dakota Trivia Trails
description: In South Dakota Trivia Trails, players "pursue" trivia questions along the game board. Players race to get to the trivia questions spots and answer the questions first. The game appears to be published by a South Dakota tourist organization.

name: Spirit of Utah Centennial Board Game
description:
From the publisher: Spirit of Utah is an exciting new board game that teaches Utah's fascinating history as you play.

Game features:
An exciting and accurate re-creation of Utah's heritage.
The element of chance.
The accumulation of points towards winning the game.
Variations of play to offer challenging levels of interest to all ages.

name: Babar and His Friends: See-Saw Game
description:
Each player chooses to be Babar the Elephant or Zephir the Monkey. Set the See-Saw to 0 for both players. The first player uses the spinner and moves the See-Saw up towards his Pop of Gold as many spaces as the spinner indicates. This will cause the other player's character to go down towards the alligator's mouth. Now the other player spins, and moves the See-Saw up, causing the first players character to go down. Play continues like this until one player reaches the Pot of Gold.

Not the most skilful game in the world!!

Listed in American Games, #44493. 1960, Literary, Board game.
categories: Animals, Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Novel-based

name: Autofun
description:
Motorized Race GameIt’s wild and it’s fun!
Cars race! Bells ring!
1-2-3-4-then you win!!

Battery powered cars
Remote controlled switches
Automatic score counters

Up to four can play
For all kids 7 to 107
Singles or teams!!


Listed in American Games, #4491. 1963, Travel, Board Game.

name: Apple's Way
description:
Listed in American Games, #4488. 1974, TV, Board Game. Based on the short lived eponymous 1974 television series.

Object of game: The Apple family likes to do things together and in this game, the players have fun matching cards of their many activities. As players move around the path of the board, they try to stop on certain squares so they can pick up a green card that would show some activity that would match a yellow card in their hand. When a player has matched a green card from the board with a yellow card from their hand, both cards are discarded and out of the game. Green and yellow are common apple colors, after all!

The winner of the game is the first player to discard all of his cards.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Air Combat
description: Listed in American Games, #4471. 1968, Military, Board game.

name: Bobbin Noggin
description:
Featured on the television show "Shenanigans" prior to release. ("Shenanigans" was sponsored by Milton Bradley.)

Listed in American Games, #4519. 1964, Skill, Action game.

A test of skill and coordination. Bobbin Noggin is a head and hat connected by a length of elastic. The player grips the top of the hat which has a light magnetic attraction for the metallic head. By jiggling the elastic the player can bounce the head close enough to be caught in the hat. The hard part it to place the hat squarely on Bobbin head.
Good fun for ages 5 to 12.

name: Batman Mini Board Card Game
description:
The Batman mini-board game is a race game played with cards controlling movement. There are 24 spaces on the board from start to finish. It has a small 3x9.75 inch cardboard game board with illustrations of Batman's famous villain foes.

Listed in American Games, #4502. 1964, Super Hero, Card game.
categories: Card Game, Comic Book / Strip, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Bugs Bunny Adventure Game
description:
Bugs Bunny has invited his some of his friends to go with him to his Carrot Castle. Along the path he has stationed more of his friends to show the way. Some of them help while others turn mischievous and try to hinder the players as they go along.

The Bugs Bunny Adventure Game is a classic 50s Role and Move Game with various locations that send you forward/back or gain/lose you a turn. The interesting twist was that each player had to get both of their 'Warner Brothers' Cartoon Characters home to win and that meant that a player could think carefully move their characters in order to increase the chance of hitting good spots and limit the risk of bad spots.

Source: Game Box Insert & User summary

Listed in American Games, #4531a/4532. 1950s/1961, Cartoons, Board game.
categories: Children's Game, Comic Book / Strip, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Tic-tac-aroo with Captain Kangaroo
description:
Listed in American Games, #4539. 1956, TV, Board game.

Submit a better description and contact Admin Skelebone for a GeekGold reward.

name: Captain and the Kids
description:
Listed in American Games, #4542. 1947, Comics, Board game.

Submit a better description and contact Admin Skelebone for a GeekGold reward.

name: Cherry Street
description:
Listed in American Games, #4559. 1966, TV, Mystery, Board game.

(Listed as a TV-based mystery game, but I am unable to find an associated television show).

Submit a better description and contact Admin Skelebone for a GeekGold reward.

name: Choo Choo Charlie Game
description:
Listed in American Games, #4567. 1946, Travel, Rails, Board game.

Players travel around the candy ties of the railroad tracks attempting to collect cards. The first player to reach the candy box, with three cards of one kind, is the winner.
There are 3 types of cards, white and pink candy cards, and good and plenty cards, these are wild cards.
Players roll and move along the white and pink ties, the yellow squares and railroad crossing count as one space. Players attempt to collect three cards of a kind white or pink. When a player reaches the "crossing" space he may choose to go on either circular track. Once started he must continue to travel clockwise around the circle. When a player reaches the "switch" space he must choose to continue around the circle if he does not have cards for "three of a kind". If he has "three of a kind" he may race for the candy box at the finish. The first player to land on the candy box by exact count wins the game.

name: Cut Up Shopping Spree Game
description:
Listed in American Games, #4586. 1968, Economic, Board game.

Imagine! You spend all the money you cut out of a money sheet to shop for clothes fro your own model. A spinner tells you how much time you have for cutting. You race against a time clock and must be fast with the scissors to be the first player to “Cut-Up” enough money to completely outfit your model.

name: Dinosaurus
description: Educational game for children about dinosaurs published in the '80s by Nathan.

name: Montezuma
description:
Abstract game (goal of the game is to place five pawns in a row) with mexican hero (Montezuma) theme.

The game is mentioned at Gamers Alliance: "Montezuma (Wales Game Systems, 1952) uses a scoring based on bonuses for each completed row of 5 or more. There are also penalties for blocking an opponent's row of 4. The board consists of squares of different colors which enter into the determination of bonuses and penalties."

1930! is a game that requires 5 players and you each take leadership of one of the major powers of the time; Great Britain, Germany, France, Russia or Italy. There are also a number of (initially) neutral minor powers countries such as Spain, Belgium, Ireland etc etc. Each country has two key properties: Military strength and Political strength. The territory held and political points value of a country determine its military strength.

One of the key features to the game is ability to influence a minor power using your political points. If enough are used then there is a chance the minor power will be come friendly (allowing passage through their territory) or even allied (allowing use of their military).

Like Diplomacy, orders are written down and executed simultaneously. In 1930! the orders include everything from movement to application of political power. Conflicts that arise are resolved according the combat strength of the forces involved with a simple percentage roll. In between turns it's time to make and break alliances with the other major power players.

From the game designer:

'1930! is my attempt to produce a game that retains a set of simple rules and the personal interaction found with Diplomacy, but extends the game play to include aircraft, the political or economic power of countries and many more neutral countries. '
categories: Bluffing, Negotiation, Political, Print & Play, Wargame, World War I, World War II
mechanics: Area Movement, Player Elimination, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Word Chess
description:
Although the legal moves in this game are defined by a list of 88 words, Word Chess is more like a battle than a word game. Players have contrasting sets of tiles, and each turn they place tiles on the board or move existing tiles, four at a time, on squares of their own color. Each set includes one X and five each of N (which can be rotated to form a Z), E (which can also be used as M or W), and O. The object is to get an X to the last rank, or to capture the opponent's X by surrounding it. Moves can only be made adjacent to previously placed tiles, and all of a player's tiles must form words diagonally at the end of each turn.

(Description from Nov. 1984 GAMES Magazine, p. 33)

name: Acorn
description:
Tribes of oak harvesters line a small valley, preparing to plant their trees in the fields below. They come to the valley in two waves, seeking to control the fields and to capture opponents' seedlings.Points are scored for controlling the planted fields. Most points at the end of the second round wins. Captured seeds are used as a tie-breaker. Two or three can play, using the same rules.

An entry into the About.com: 2003 Simultaneous Movement Game Design Competition.

name: Hunt the Hare
description:
This is an abstract strategy game where one player has four hares that must switch spaces (two switching with two). The other player has hounds that he uses to try to catch the hares.

The game rules are printed inside the lid of the box.

name: The Messenger
description: This is an old game (1800s or early 1900s) that has a board made of squares numbered 1 to 65, with stars in place of some of the numbers. There is a jail in the top right corner where players go if they miscount or play out of turn (cheat?). The game includes a spinner, and there are four playing pieces to go with it. It is a typical spin-and-move game of the era.

name: After Dinner: Seven Games for an Evening's Entertainment
description:
"After Dinner": Seven Games for an Evening's Entertainment contains rules/questions/answers for seven different games.

The games are:

Where Are the Counterfeiters?
The Treasure Hunt
Are You a Good Witness?
For Back and Front Seat Drivers
Reading and Riting and Rithmetic
Rebuses
Advice to the Love Torn

name: Drop in the Bucket
description:
Game contains foam blocks and a mesh bucket on a belt. The players fasten the belt so that the mesh bucket is in back. The other players try to drop foam blocks in your basket and visa-versa.

Listed in American Games, #4608. 1960s, Skill, Action game.

name: F Troop Mini-Board Card Game
description:
Listed in American Games, #4625. 1965, TV, Board game.

Submit a better description and contact Admin Skelebone for a GeekGold reward.

name: Fireball XL5
description:
A children's board game based on the "Supermarionation" (marionette) sci-fi TV series produced by Gerry Anderson in the early 1960s.

The players race jet mobiles along a 13 space track. The playing board illustrates the patrol rocket Fireball XL5 on its launch rail.

The game components include the board, twelve cardboard stand-up pieces (three for each player - two robots and one human), twelve plastic stands in four colors (matching the color of the stand-ups), and two six-sided dice. The instructions are printed on the inside of the box lid.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction

name: Flagship Airfreight, The Airline Cargo Game
description:
The goal of the game is to deliver special packages via air freight by the quickest and most direct route to ten different destinations in the United States. The first player to aquire 10 special package cards for having made 10 complete trips wins the game.

Listed in American Games, #4640. 1946, Travel, Air, Board game.
mechanics: Network and Route Building, Pick-up and Deliver

name: Fun on the Farm
description:
Object of game:
The fun of the game is to visit the farm, and see the animals. Its purpose is to entertain the younger children. It also serves to teach the child the fun of fair play. This game is basically a simple spinner game it is a race to the finish.

name: Gordo and Pepito
description:
Listed in American Games, #4670. 1947, Comics, Board game.

The directions to play the game are printed on the underside of the lid. This game is for two, three, or four players and has one die and four character pawns - Gordo, Pepito, Juan Pablo Jones and the Poet. All players start at the space picturing Gordo and Pepito. The object of the game is to move your character pawn along the path of sombreros on the board and be the first to arrive in the space picturing Juan Pablo Jones and the Poet.

If the player lands on a Black Sombrero, s/he must take a "siesta" and miss a turn. If all four players end up taking a siesta, they all roll and the highest number rolls again to resume play.

name: Happy Face Game
description:
Listed in American Games, #4682. 1968, Kiddie, Board game.

The game board consists of a curving track with each space being marked with a face (Happy, Smile, Funny, Surprise or Hide. The cards also reflect these faces.
In a turn, a player draws a card and must move his playing piece to the next space on the track showing that face.
There are two special spaces marked in red, 'Sad' and 'Crying' faces. There is only one of each of these faces. If you draw one of these, you must go to that relative space even if it means moving backwards.
The first player to get to the Happy face at the end of the track, wins.

To add more fun for younger players, it is suggested that when they look at their card, they should try to copy the face to the amusement of other players

name: The Ipcress File
description:
“The IPCRESS File,” a board game issued in 1966 by Milton Bradley. Game No. 4643.

A espionage game modeled after the popular 1965 British espionage film
starring Michael Caine as “Harry Palmer,” and Len Deighton’s 1962 novel, “The IPCRESS File.”
Other actors and scenes are shown in a small collage.
The gameboard has a simple track and four well-drawn illustration scenes.

The movie was aimed at an adult audience, perhaps reaching some teenagers.
The game is marked as 'from 10 to adult'.
The game is incredibly simple and lacking in sustained interest.

It is a chasing game.
Up to four players move around a board representative of scenes from the film.
Players are given spy assignments, but one player secretly becomes a double agent.
Those playing are required to solve their assignments so that they can identify the double agent.
Any player who knows who the double agent is is then 'licensed to kill' the double agent and thereby win the game.

The game is a little dull; but as a marketing tie-in and ephemeral item, it has interest.


content:
1 board
12 Classified cards
12 Confidential cards
four agent pawns consisting of a cardboard panel and plastic base
two red-and-gold dice
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Spies/Secret Agents

name: Kigmy Game by Al Capp
description:
Listed in American Games, #4725. 1950, Comics, Skill game.

Based on cartoonist Al Capp's "Kigmy," a strange, dark, big-nosed creature that loved to be kicked. Naturally, the Kigmy ("Kick-Me") was welcomed by humans, who loved nothing more than taking their daily frustrations out on a creature who loved to be kicked. Al Capp is renowned for his comic "Li'l Abner" as well as other various creations, including "Shmoo."

Submit a better description and contact Admin Skelebone for a GeekGold reward.

name: The Legend of Jesse James Game
description:
Based on the eponymous television show.

Object of the Game: Jesse James and his Gang of Outlaws have robbed a train, placing the “loot” into Saddlebags. While being chased by a posse, the gang hid the Saddlebags in the rocks at seven different places along the road. They escaped the posse by the separating, each going to his own “hideout”. Later they came out to recover the “loot”. In this game, the players are members of the Jesse gang who come from their Hideouts, to ravel around the road, pick up the Saddlebags and carry them back to their Hideouts. They compete with each other in gathering the most Loot. They even try to steal a Saddlebag from their opponents by means of a gunfight. The bags may change hand several times as the outlaws continually circle the board trying to get their Loot safely into their Hideouts. The one getting the most Loot into his Hideout wins the game.
categories: American West, Movies / TV / Radio theme
mechanics: Pick-up and Deliver, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Little Lulu Adventure Game
description:
Boardgame based on the Comic Little Lulu by cartoonist Marjorie Henderson Buell (artist name: Marge).

Listed in American Games, #4750. 1946, Comics, Board game.

Submit a better description and contact Admin Skelebone for a GeekGold reward.

name: Roots and Shoots
description:
Roots and Shoots is an abstracted territory control game in which you are plants searching for delectable nutrients and hoping for rain before the others encroach.

Equipment:

* a uniquely colored set of glass beads or stones for each player
* go board
* a set of dice for each player containing d4,d6,d8,d10,d12, and d20
* stack of nutrient markers (pennies or the like)

The goal of the game is to collect as many valuable nutrient markers as possible before the nutrient supply runs out or anyone's supply of beads runs out. Then the player with the highest nutrient point total wins.

Available at: http://tomgale.com/galegames/roots-and-shoots-v1.htm

name: Bridges and Boats
description:
Equipment:

* set of double 6 dominoes (28 dominoes)
* big pile of pennies or counters
* 2 six-sided dice

Bridges and Boats is a strategic war game in which the attacker is trying to get soldiers across a major river while the enemy tries to stop them.

How to Win: The game ends immediately when the last domino is taken from the resource pool. At game end the attacker wins if more soldier units have crossed the river than the defender has collected units of money. Otherwise the defender wins. If the soldier/money unit count is tied at endgame then the conflict is tied; so be it.

name: Santa Fe' Trail
description:
From the box cover:
"A game that takes you over the most famous of all trails in the days of the Indians. Travel in a covered wagon with the pioneers."

This is a basic spin and move race game.

name: La Chasse au Mammouth
description:
La Chasse au Mammouth (=Hunt for Mammoths) was published in the Swiss gaming zine "AHA/Der Schwarze Peter" #88/4.

The board shows a glacier with 6 mammoth trails and several human trails crossing them. Player camps, weapon directory, and storehouses are also on the board.

Up to 2 Mammoth herds (4 at the start of the game) enter the board every turn and travel along their trails.

Each player starts with 20 tribesmen and 5 x 5 weapons of 5 different types. The well armed tribesmen go out to hunt some mammoths, which are needed to feed the population. The weapons used to kill a mammoth are removed from the game, that is they represent more a consumable arrow than an bow, that can be used all the time.

Every second turn, it is checked to see how many tribesmen can be fed (with half a mammoth per man). Men who are not fed are flipped over and all their abilities are halved for the next turn. Subsequent non-feeding will result in the elimination of the men.

While hunting mammoths is relatively easy at the start of the game, it gets harder and harder, because players must manufacture new weapons and pitfalls and thus only some of the men can be used for hunting.

The game ends, when the first player has lost all tribesmen. Winner is the player who has the most surviving men on the board at that time.

name: Das Umzugsspiel
description:
Das Umzugsspiel ("Change of Residence") was published in the Swiss gaming zine "AHA/Der schwarze Peter" #89/1.

The board shows a fictive city map with a furniture warehouse in the middle and 4 residences in each corner.

Object of the game is to move his 7 furniture pieces from the starting residence to the residence at the opposing edge of the board with the help of 1 van per player.

Movements are done by dice rolls, but 54 also included cards influence the movements heavily. Fortunately, only 26 cards must be used immediately. The remaining 28 cards give more room to avoid too much bad luck.

4 mobile road works (=obstacles) hinder the players to move where they want and the fact that loosing furniture pieces is also possible (must be replaced by picking new furnitures in the furniture warehouse) does not only make the game more interesting, it also gives the feeling of a real change of residence - with all possible frustrating experiences.

Winner of the game is the player who has moved his furnitures to the target domicile first.
mechanics: Open Drafting, Pick-up and Deliver, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Atomic
description:
A game for two that's a real blast! An abstract game with a connection element -- be the player that has the most pieces showing in your color by the end of the game.

Equipment:

* An hexagonal grid, in the shape of a hexagon, containing 61 hexes.
* Two sets of 30 double-sided hexagonal pieces:
o 12 Connectors (one line joining two opposite sides) with the opponent's 12 Alternators on the reverse side
o 12 Alternators (three lines joining three, alternating sides) with the opponent's 12 Connectors on the reverse side),
o 3 Destructors (six lines joining all sides) with the opponent's 3 Burn-outs on the reverse side)
o 3 Burn-outs (six lines joining all sides) with the opponent's 3 Destructors on the reverse side

A play consists of one of placing one marker - face-up with the colour of the player whose turn it is - on any unoccupied space on the board. The player then traces a path ('reaction') through as many pieces of the opposing colour as he can. A path is a continuous line passing from a piece of the player's colour to one of his opponent's. Once the path is established, the opponent's piece is flipped over and the piece rotated in such a way that at least one of the lines on it joins up to the path. If there are now no lines on the new piece that point to another opposing piece, or if the flipped piece is a Burn-out, the 'reaction' is over, and the player's turn ends.

The objective is for each player to have the most pieces showing his colour at the end of the game. If there are an equal number of each, the game is a draw.

name: Hole in the Head
description: Hole In The Head is an interesting game with even more interesting marketing by today's standards (see box photos below). The directions are on the bottom of the box and bottom of game piece. There is a hard plastic bubble-covered face with different holes in the eyes, ears, nose and mouth. There is a magnet attached to a string (inside a wooden ball) and inside the game there are 5 ball bearing type balls. You use the magnet to maneuver the balls.

name: Commodity
description:
Commodity is a buying and selling game that is not meant to simulate real life, although there are some similarities.

Ages 12 and up can play Commodity. Younger children can play with an adult and may even win!

The object of Commodity is:

1. To make money by buying and selling.
2. To pay off all debts.
3. To manage your company to gain wealth.

Commodity can be played to different limits which the players can set at the beginning of (or during) the game. For example, an average game would be set at $1,000,000, a shorter game at $500,000 and a longer game at $2,000,000.

To win Commodity, a player must:

1. Be debt free.
2. Reach the limit set by the players.
3. Declare a win.

In order to declare a win, a player must state, ON HIS TURN, that he has met or gone beyond the set limit. This player then completes his turn. The other players now have one more turn to try and defeat the declaring player. The player with the most money at the end wins. A player DOES NOT have to declare a win until he chooses to do so.

See www.markallangames.com for more information.

name: Central Pennsylvania Trivia Game
description:
From the publisher: This fun trivia board game brings the wonders of Central Pennsylvania to life for the entire family.

Central Pennsylvania Trivia Game is a party game about the Hershey area of Pennsylvania. It is designed with several levels of difficulty so that it can be enjoyed by all ages. Players roll and move around the outside track of the board and answer questions based on the spot they land in. A unique feature in this trivia game is the players may choose to answer with or without hints.

name: Rose City Trivia
description: Rose City Trivia is a party game about the city of Portland designed with several levels of difficulty so that it can be enjoyed by all ages. Players roll and move around the outside track of the board and answer questions based on the spot they land in. A unique feature in this trivia game is the players may choose to answer with or without hints. The game includes over 1,600 trivia questions!

name: Behold
description:
Behold: The Christian Knowledge Game

A Bible trivia game. Players roll the "Symbolized Cube" to move their marker to the next matching category square on the board. Then they answer questions in that category to collect a Passage card. When the player has collected all four styles of Passage cards, they attempt to recite the verses from memory to win the game. Players may return to a category to trade their Passage card for a different one.

Contents:
500 Question cards
100 Passage cards
10 Player tokens
1 Symbolized Cube (no dice).
mechanics: Memory, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Madison Trivia
description: Players answer trivia questions about Madison, Wisconsin, trying to move three game pieces into the center of the board to win.

name: The Merry Game Of The Country Auction
description: This is a simple auction game "depicting" a rural country auction. Items up for bid are various pieces of farm equipment.

name: Giraffe
description: The object of the game is to spin the spinner, and add the number of neck pieces to the body, without making it collapse. To win the game you must use up all your neck pieces and put the head on. The game components are: 1 base tray, 1 Giraffe body, 1 Giraffe head, 1 spinner, 28 pegs, instructions, box, and cardboard insert.

name: Travel Manners of the Wealthy and Powerful
description:
This is a simple trivia game that only Ms. Manners could love. The only component is a 50-card deck with 6 questions on each card.

Sample questions:
A slap on the back to a European is considered a pure sign of friendship, true or false?

It is improper to address a man or woman of equal age or status as Sir or Madam, true or false.

The game is not from Funtastic Games of the 1960's, but FunTastic Games of Charlotte, NC.

name: Tumble-Numbers
description:
Tumble-Numbers is an interesting dice game similar to Shut the Box except that instead of a box with fixed numbers (1 to 9), it uses a set of ten red six-sided dice with non-standard numbers (as high as 10 and including blanks) to generate the numbers that have to be eliminated by rolling a pair of ordinary green six-sided dice.

The blanks can be used to represent any positive number but must always be removed together with another red die not showing a blank.

A player keeps on rolling the green dice and removing red dice that add up to the total on the green dice at each turn. When the player cannot do this, they take the sum on the remaining red dice as their penalty score (blanks count 20 points). When the player manages to get rid of all red dice, they subtract 10 points.

When a player reaches 100 points or more, he/she has to drop out. The last surviving player is the winner.

name: My First 3 Nature Games
description:
Enjoyable adventures with animals in the form of dominoes, memory cards and an ancient board game. Leading children to the discovery of nature and helping to strengthen essential learning skills, all games are combined in a smaller 3-drawer storage box made of durable, recycled materials.

For players ages 3 and up, these games are the perfect pace and stimulation for younger ones. Contents: Baby Animals Memory Game (9 large "Mother" cards and 18 "Baby" cards); Who's Afraid of the Fox? (1 large game board, 4 figurines, 1 illustrated die); and Hide- And-Seek Dominoes (28 dominoes that show animals unique ways of protecting themselves). Grade "A" according to ToyTips.com, and a special gift to share especially with young ones.
publishers: Bioviva, Kvale Good Natured Games, LLC

name: Prognos
description: A Zodiac-themed Parcheesi-variant. Players move glass beads across the board from their starting position to target positions and back again. They draw cards to determine these target locations, which represent planets and zodiac signs. Die rolls determine how far a player can move. First visit all targets and return all beads wins.
mechanics: Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Atlantic City Tycoon
description: Subtitled "The Ultimate Casino Dice Game", Atlantic City Tycoon is a roll-and-move game that has four dice games incorporated within it: Beat the Dealer, Chuck a Luck, Under and Over Seven, and Hazard. The game is clearly aimed at the family market but the dice games are real and the game tries to simulate a fun night in ACY.
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Game of Old Mrs. Goose
description: Child's Spin and Move Game from Milton Bradley (#4740) comes with a spinner and 4 colored men. The spiral shaped board has special colored dots (Black, white and Red) which have special rules for them (lose turn, spin again, etc.)

name: Tuunes
description:
Tunes is played either by two players or two teams. The game is played by selecting a card that has the notes for a popular melody printed on it. This card is placed in a special holder with numerous slots that can open to reveal one note at a time. Numbered tiles are then drawn randomly from a bag that tell which note to reveal. The melody that is visible is then sang, sight-read, or played on an instrument. The player who is able to identify the melody with the least amount of notes shown is the winner.

The game includes card packs for various genres of music including classical and religious hymns.

name: Sturmpioniere
description:
One of the more interesting wargame designs coming out of Nazi Germany.

The game features 4 duplicate triangular maps of the field of battle that can be placed together to form a square board. Each section of the map contains 90 points with various obstacles that must be overcome (minefields, hedgehogs, wire fences) or repaired (blown bridges, destroyed roads). The playing pieces are metal miniatures (painted flats) consisting of German Sappers with various implements (explosives, wire cutters, Flame-thrower, etc.) and a tank.

The sappers move based on a die roll, in any combination the player desires. The object of the game is to overcome obstacles by gathering the right combination of sappers at the obstacle which is either then destroyed or repaired for the rest of the game. The final obstacle is a bunker that sits on the intersection of all four boards and must be destroyed to win the game.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: The Ocean Race
description: A Spears roll-and-move game featuring metal pawns shaped like boats. One of many Spears roll-and-move games of the period.

name: The Tram
description: A simple roll-and-move game featuring what, at the time, was cutting edge transportation.

name: Battle at Sea: The New Game of National Defense
description:
From the rules - Battle at Sea, the new game of National Defense, is played on a cloth surface which is marked with two sea lanes of 16 spaces each.

Players assume control of a fleet and moves his fleet through his respective sea lane attempting to sink as many ships of the enemy fleet as possible. When one fleet has been moved completely through its sea lane, the battle is over. The player who sinks the greatest amount of enemy tonnage is the winner.

Special embossed dice are used to determine hits. Gunnery ranges, destroyers laying smoke screens, and aircraft carriers allow for varied game play.

A very rare game of naval combat

name: Plasticopoli
description:
This game was designed to popularize plastic recycling in a time in which it was still pretty unusual, at least in Italy. Players must set a collection of 4 diofferent plastic objects, getting them from leftovers of plastic. Double objects can be either traded or destroyed to get more raw materials. Leftovers can also be burned to get energy.

The game has been published as a large magazine to be diostributed for free in schools all over Italy.

"Il gioco dei minerali" is reminescent of this game: Il Gioco dei Minerali
categories: Economic, Educational, Environmental, Industry / Manufacturing, Memory, Negotiation
mechanics: Memory, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: The Juno Mission
description:
Players are astronauts that have arrived at Star City for their final phase of training. Only one player will join the two Cosmonauts on a trip to the Mir Space Station.

In this roll and move game, you must collect a Pass Card for languages, medical fitness and technical skills and get to the Launch Pad first.

In the Advanced Game, the game lasts 26 turns (weeks) and the winner of the game is the player who reaches the Launch Pad having collected the most points from going round the board, with Pass Cards from the Basic Game counting as 5 points.

name: Pog Baseball
description:
From the publishers website:

POG Baseball combines the Classic Game of POG with the real action of baseball. You can score a run, hit a triple or strike out. You must outscore your opponent by flipping over the most POG. The player who scores more points wins the game! Includes 22 POG, 2 Slammers, 1 Game board, 1 Die, 1 Official Rule Sheet and 1 Score Pad.

Reimplements: Pogs

name: Pog Basketball
description:
From the publishers website:

POG Basketball combines the Classic Game of POG with the real action of basketball. You can make 3 point shots and slam dunks but be careful, you can also shoot an air ball. You must outscore your opponent by flipping over the most POG. The player who scores more points wins the game! Includes 22 POG, 2 Slammers, 1 Game board, 1 Die, 1 Official Rule Sheet and 1 Score Pad.

Reimplements: Pogs

name: Pog Football
description:
From the publishers website:

POG Football combines the Classic Game of POG with the real action of football. You can get a first down or score a touchdown but be careful you can also fumble the ball. You must outscore your opponent by flipping over the most POG. The player who scores more points wins the game! Includes 22 POG, 2 Slammers, 1 Game board, 1 Die, 1 Official Rule Sheet and 1 Score Pad.

Reimplements: Pogs

name: Conquering Hollywood
description:
Conquering Hollywood is the first board game about what it is really like to be in California making your dream of success in the movie business a reality. It's also the first game with "Personality Power," a way to compete with other players outside of the game itself ... that counts in the game.

The game of Conquering Hollywood is based on "Personality Power." That means everything you say and everything you do counts in the game. Even things you say and do "outside the game."

Conquering Hollywood is a cutthroat look at the true ways and means of Tinseltown. Actors! Producers! Directors! Writers! Just a Nobody? Get a car and pick up a screenplay. Compete with other players to make hit movies. Whether you're a nobody or a player, everyone in Tinseltown wants to be King of Hollywood! But there is only one King and his joy lasts only 15 minutes after an intense, hand-to-hand battle. To succeed at the game of Conquering Hollywood, you have to compete with the same people who used to be your friends. You have to compete all the time without losing concentration for a second. Compete for what? For possession of the things you need to make hit movies.

To "make it" in the movie biz in this game you need the following items: story, game, money, talent, style, vision, fight, grind, luck, call, wires, and looks.

name: Waterloo
description:
Very little is known about this game. The map shows a area from Versailles and Paris on one side and Brussels and Namur on the other. Key towns/cities (in gold) include Quatre Bras and Ligny.

It seems to be a forerunner for Kreigspiel Junior with its point to point movement system. The gameboard is the top of the box (wooden) which also has a slot for the game pieces.

Two of the five known copies are part of the Angiolillo collection.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: The Game of 5th Column Spy Hunters
description:
To quote the rules: "Every 5th Columnist Spy that is caught pays the full penalty for his crime whether this country is at peace or at war. For a while a 5th Columnist spy may escape detection and cause much damage and many heartaches… but from the days of old... No 5th Columnist Spy has yet escaped." Excerpted from the rules section A Word About Spies by James Boyle - Former Special Investigator.

5th Column Spy Hunter is a point to point movement game for 2 teams. Players act as either the 5th Columnists or the Spy Hunters and move around a map of the United States based on Official Number Code from the Decoder (a spinner). The spinner provides moves based on a separate "code" list for 5th Columnists and Spy Hunters. 5th Columnists score points for ending their moves on designated spots (for example: air naval or army bases to steal documents), the Spy Hunters get points based on failures by the 5th Columnists. The winner is the first team to 15 points. Both teams are expected to record their routes so that a second game can be played to crown the "Champion Spy Hunter". The teams exchange routes and take turns listing the order of the states they entered and their capitols. Points are awarded for correct answers. Mistakes cost a team their turn. The Champion is the team with the highest score.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Schachy
description: A chess variant on a larger board with more pieces per player. A die roll determines which kind of chess move can be made with a piece in the player's turn.

name: Latest Game of Knights, Tournaments, and Saracens for Young and Old
description: Beautiful game created via lithography in Nuremberg, despite the impressive name, it appears to be a simple roll-and-move game. It's pictured in Games We Play.

name: New Traveling Game by Railway from Berlin to Paris
description: A game created via lithograph in Nuremberg. It's pictured in Games We Play, and the box cover is both beautiful and very impressive for 1840.

name: The New Game of the Monkey
description: A very simple spin-and-move game, intended to be played with a tee-totem. As with similar games, player race along a track, attempting to be the first to reach the finish. A few spaces on the track have a special effect.

name: Historical-Chronological Game
description: Mentioned in Games We Play as one of the earliest published games, used by Gutsmuths categorization of games, which was published in 1796.

name: Geographical Card Game
description: Mentioned in Games We Play as one of the earliest games, it was mentioned in Gutsmuths' 1796 book that created a classification method for all games.

name: Throne and Cottage
description: According to Games We Play, this is the predecessor to Bell and Hammer.

name: Yacht Race
description: A simple roll-and-move game from Spears in a period when they were releasing several such games in any given year.

name: Word Builder
description: The forerunner to Scrabble, this Spears game had everything Scrabble has except the crossword element.

name: High Speed Test: Dunlop Tyre Racing Game
description: CHAD VALLEY Dunlop Tyre Racing Game called HIGH SPEED TEST... The first part of the game you travel around each department of the Dunlop Tire Company where you manufacture tires. Then in the second part of the game you test those tires on the race track, The game has a built in spinner and comes with 3 lead racing cars. The board has a nice picture illustration of the Dunlop Factory in its center.

name: Motor Delivery Game
description: Die driven race game from Chad Valley. Games comes with 4 lead racing cars, a die and a game board. The object of the game is to be the first one to deliver a new motor vehicle to town.

name: Tree Top Targets game
description: Chad Valley shooting game which comes with a cork rifle and cellulose targets that look like Christmas Balls on a tree.

name: Stolen Treasure
description:
From the publisher's website:

Diamonds, bonds, gems, art classics and money are up for grabs in this new test of spy and intrigue. Each asset requires a special set of tools to successfully heist the treasure. Once a player successfully acquires a treasure, the goal is to avoid the CIA and thieves to capture the most points and victory.

name: Game: The Gaming
description:
Game: the Gaming is a non-collectible card game for two to six players in which you play some of the Big RPG Companies, all struggling to churn out new product and rake in as much profit as you can from rehashed old concepts and tired system mechanics. The trick is to latch onto hot new concepts and milk them for all they're worth before the ever-fickle target audience (predominantly males age 12-22) either turn to the next new thing or have to find a real job and move out of mom's basement.

G:tG is a general spoof of the entire Gaming industry, and should be taken entirely for the good-hearted fun that it is (especially by any of the aforementioned Big Gaming Companies who may have Big Legal Teams...).

name: Tru Action Electric Baseball Game
description: TRU Action Electric Baseball game by Tudor featured a spring loaded bat and a magnet that was used as a ball. The pitching device threw the ball at a target which stood upright behind the batters side of the field. on that target was BALL. STRIKE and WILD PITCH. Once the "ball was thrown at the "plate" the batter sitting behind the wall which was the plate used the spring loaded bat to strike the target plate hitting the ball in the air and on to the playing field where a number of circles were marked. Hitting the ball into a circle was an out. Little men similar to those used in vibrating football games of the same ilk were used as base runners and "ran around the bases once the power was turned on. A "fence or wall" was also situated after the outfield and any hit "ball that stuck to the wall higher than the fence was a HOME RUN.

name: Hop-Scotch
description: From the makers of Pass-Out comes another drinking game that doesn't necessarily require alcohol to be enjoyed. Players roll move around the board to collect letters spelling H O P S C O T C H G A M E with the first player to do so becoming the winner. Many of the spaces landed on will require players to take a drink.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: My House
description:
Taken from the Opstelten Speelgoed website.

Where are the toothbrushes to be found at your house? Do they belong in the kitchen, the bathroom or maybe in both? And what about your toys? Do they belong in the Living room or in your bedroom? In any case not in the bathroom. Then they better be stored in the attic. With the game My House children can playfully tell how things are organized at their home. It’s all about telling about their experiences from home. Becoming aware of the arrangement of things at home and thus familiar in their own house.

It is interesting and fun to hear for the parents, hearing their children talk about how they think about the arrangements at home. The children for their part become very resourceful in substantiating their ideas about the location of the objects. But My House offers even more. The older children can play memory games with it or call forth all their linguistic skills in a game of “Linguistic Happy Families”. Thus the game co-develops along with the development of the linguistic skills of the child. Ranging from story telling up to in their own words finding synonyms to complete their set of “Happy Families”!

name: NewLondonAreaopoly
description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μόνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεῖν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

Typical fundraiser type Monopoly game.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Cinderella or Hunt the Slipper
description: Hunt for the Slipper is an old game which features cards that represent the Chicago Police Department and also smaller cards that represent different things that might be missing. Looks like the game plays like a rummy game.

name: Empires
description:
Based on game play mechanics Empires seems to be the precursor to games like Risk.

From the rules:

Empires is played on a world map; the individual players representing "Powers" which include; the United States, Great Britain, France, Russia, Italy and Japan. The object is for one player to establish a World Empire and eliminate all other players from the game.

Parts include 6 pawns representing each country, 20 Markers for each player, 48 resource cards and 48 armament cards with values of 1 or 5 representing Air, Navy and Army units.

Players start in the start box and move from point to point around the world map, landing on free territories (gaining a resource card), colonies (placing a marker to control and taking resources) and blockades (if owned then 2 resources are owned to the controlling player). Resources can be converted into armaments, 3 resources for 1 randomly drawn armament. Once all colonies are taken a colonial war begins and as players land on opposing colonies they may choose an armament class and announce an attack. The player with the highest strength wins the battle and takes the colony. If he loses he loses resources equal to the colonies values.

The final stage is total war when all armaments are gone. The first player back to start challenges the other players to war and compares values for all armaments, winner take all. Last man standing wins.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Quiz Me: Game of Numbers
description: Milton Bradley distributed this Trivia type game in 1938. The box claims that this is "An exciting game of questions and Answers about things that everyone should know.

name: A Game of the States
description: A Game of States is copyrighted from 1887 by O.F. Decker M.D. Buffalo, N.Y.. The game has Geographical and Historical questions on 70 cards for a total of 700 questions. The game box states that Every question is Answered by the Name at the top of the Card. he game sold for 75 cents

name: Hänsel und Gretel: Ein Märchenspiel
description:
(translated: Hansel and Gretel - A Fairy Tale Game)

Probably from the 1950s.

A simple roll and move course with events from the Grimm fairy tale. The board has die-cut holes in it instead of spaces, it stays in place of the box.
On the box's edge is a short wooden lever which can be used as a stand to keep the board at a slight angle. The playing pieces are colored pottery balls which are moved from hole to hole - some holes are larger than the balls - should a die roll or an event (explained in the box's lid) bring your piece to such a hole, your ball falls through, rolls to a chute on the lower end of the board and you will have to start again. The mechanism is similar to Cat & Mice or Holes & Traps.

name: Kreuz und quer durch den grünen Harz
description:
(translation: Cross-country through the green Harz (a mountain region in Germany))
A simple roll-and-move game, where two groups of players each take a different route through the region (both routes have the same number of spaces and share several spaces with each other). If players reach certain spaces on the board, they have to read educational texts about the cities and villages of the region.

name: Bombers Aloft
description:
From the rules:

There are four lanes of travel. The first spin selects the lane of travel. Player 1 spins again and sets the bomber's altitude. The nose of the bomber is placed in the metal stand provided at the height noted. A third spin gives the movement value.

The AA gun spins next (2 times to set the lane and altitude). If they match the lane and height of the bomber it is brought down. Each player follows in succession with a bomber and then the AA gun's attack. If the AA score a kill it gets points based on the zone the bomber is in and its altitude.

The lanes contain spaces with numbers (from 1 to 14) that reference the hit on the score card. The value is recorded as part of the score. Any plane that comes to a "Change Altitude" space spins the spinner for a new altitude.

The game ends when all bombers have been shot down or have reached the finish line. The player with the largest score is the winner.

name: Basic Fleet Combat System
description:
